item.title: Issue #21 for Thursday the 7th of November 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason, where I put a little shugah on it. Back to the archive.

Issue #21 for Thursday the 7th of November 2013

This one goes out to all the purple elephpants in the audience.

I know I'm a little late getting this issue out, given my overly exuberant claims to keep this ship rolling last issue, but illness struck me down this weekend, like a segfault on the main cluster.

The initial response to the big PHP Weekly reboot was AWESOMESAUCE, so a big thank you to everyone, I'm going to draw and contact winners for the following prizes this weekend, so if you haven't already put your name down one or both of the prizes and you want a chance to win, then email me:
  1. 1 Personal License of JetBrains PhpStorm
  2. 2 copies of Cal Evan's new micro-book Signaling PHP
Although the scholarship has now been awarded for CodeConnexx, you can still get 10% off your ticket and attend perhaps one of the best conferences of the season (if you can get to NL by tomorrow that is).

I'm still taking names/addresses for people wanting PHP Weekly stickers, so email me if you want some for yourself, your friends, family, coworkers, user group, conference, etc.
If everyone could keep on spreading the word about PHP Weekly on Twitter/Facebook/Google+/App.net/mesenger pigeons/graffiti on toilet walls/etc., or forwarding the emails to friends/colleagues/pets/mailmen/clairvoyants/fictional characters/etc. you may think would enjoy, or help printing it out and handing it out, anything is just awesome and appreciated.

One final note from my little soapbox: although this isn't PHP specific, it is web dev and community specific, or more the point personal.
The amazing web standards guru, author and generally great person Molly Holzschlag has a rare liver condition that has left her struggling to survive on a course of drugs and chemo, with end in sight to beat it, but finances threatening make life even worse. As the FriendsOfMolly and #TeamMolly say, they know times are hard, but if you could give just a little something to help her out, then you would be helping someone in a great hour of need who has most likely either directly or indirectly made your life as a web dev much better over the years.

Some changes

I'd love it if everyone could add wes@phpweekly.info to their address books as I plan on sending future issues on from this address, and I know the list hits spam filters enough as it is right now. Also if you ever see it land in your spam box, can you let me know? I'm trying to improve this situation.

To keep the list rolling I'm going to be taking on extra editorial help, and I may even get a rota of editors together to take some pressure off, especially when I'm traveling to conferences, if you'd be interesting in helping out please let me know.

News & announcements

mt_rand() cracker released into the wild
Long story short: don't use mt_rand() for seeding anything, ever, the OpenWall project's new php_mt_seed is a very powerful implementation of their proposed mt_rand() seed cracker, and from various reports it works a treat. If you're a budding pen tester take a look, if you're a dev, use something better. (Caveat: technically if you're using Suhosin mt_rand is more secure as it is re-seeded on every call from /dev/urandom but you should not rely on this.)

Expectations RFC enters voting
The Expectations RFC defines a new backwards-breaking API for the oft-forgotten assert call which will make unit test a little bit nicer to write, and certain blocks such as switches and functions with unattainable sections easier to define with a standard exception. Voting has commenced and it's looking good for this making the cut.

GoPHP5: The Revenge
GoPHP5 was the record breaking push in 2008 to get the top PHP apps and libraries to drop PHP4 and finally move to 5, followed by many of the big PHP hosting providers. It worked and was instrumental and the PHP core team end-of-life-ing 4, thus pushing the majority of big companies, agencies, platforms, and pretty much everyone else into the world of 5.x rainbows and unicorns. Larry Garfield (♥), one of the leading voices behind the original movement, has raised the idea of another push onto 5.5+, saying goodbye at last to 5.2, 5.3 and the barely wet-nursed 5.4. The discussion is being held on the PHP-FIG mailing list presumably with the idea of getting many of the big names in frameworks to lead the way. Interesting to see if this gets the full head of steam the original did.

True North PHP Virtual Tickets go on sale
I stupidly forgot one of the highlights of the PHP conference calendar, and the premier Canada conference, True North PHP, led by a fantastic and well known team, is back this year and although it's now incredibly close and many who haven't already booked probably can't make it (as it may even be today by the time you read this), they do have virtual tickets on offer, from "it's like you're really there" teleconference tickets, to "I can watch it all the week after on the toilet" on demand tickets. Get 'em while they're hot.

php[architect] returning to print!
Big news from the crew at musketeers.me, the one-and-only php[a], will be returning to it's original print format as a yearly subscription option at a mere $119 USD.

phpDay 2014 CFP is open

Audiovisuals

It’s the Booze Talking #5 – PHP Community…again (Part #1)
Another special conference roundtable from Cal Evans' awesome Voices of the Elephant podcast, this time recorded at Zendcon 2013 featuring the dulcet tones of PHP-celebs Adam Culp (♥), Michelangelo van Dam (♥), Davey Shafik (♥), Eli White (♥), Chris Tankersly (♥), and of course Cal (♥) himself.

/dev/hell Episode 36: Maybe PHP Isn't as Lame as We Thought ♥ ♥
Chris "grmpyprogrammer" Hartjes and Ed "funkatron" Finkler return with an awesomesauce dose of HHVM, static type hinting, the usual unit testing breakdowns, reasons why PHP may have hip-language-points you didn't know about, and ending with an some brilliant thoughts from both Chris and Ed on the subject of not being a total douchebag when attending conferences, and why they're not just excuses to get plastered on a sponsor's bar tab.

Elephant in the Room podcast ♥ ♥
Although I haven't had time to catch up on this new podcast, it was recommended to me by Adrian Philipp, and it looks extremely promising, by Konstantin Kudryashovand and Mathias Verraes, both of whom may just ping your "he didn't he do X" radar, especially if you've done much unit or functional testing in PHP recently.

Articles

Debugging PHP applications with HHVM ♥ ♥
Qandidate's Alexander and Emil go step by step through using one of HHVM's less known gems, an inbuilt interactive debugger, which is a must have tool for any PHP dev (if you're not using one, get yourself an xdebug/DBGp compatible debugger now). With a simple CLI switch the HHVM runner becomes an interactive debugger with all the bells and whistles, reminiscent of Python's inbuilt pdb.

HHVM with Symfony 2 looks amazing ♥
Yes indeed, it seems to be HHVM week. Hot on the heels of last week's benchmarks, Christian Stocker shares his stats from a recent non-trivial Symfony2 application developed by Liip for interacting with the Amazon ElasticSearch API, performing some business logic, and returning results to the client. The results are extremely promising for HHVM, in comparison with vanilla PHP 5.3 and PHP 5.5+Opcache, performing at up to 50% faster (RPM, response time etc.) across the board against 5.5 (which in turn outperforms it's ageing ancestor 5.3 at 60-70%).

DTracing a PHPUnit Test: Looking at Functional Programming ♥
Christopher Jones regales us with more DTrace'in examples, this time tracing a PHPUnit test suite (from the example code in Patkos Csaba's excellent Functional Programming in PHP tutorial), and printing out the call tree using a D script and the DTrace hooks in PHP 5.5. This is a very powerful method for dynamically tracing a program with runtime hooks and manipulation that you only get from something like DTrace with the powerful D language as an orchestration utility.

Introduction to Gearman – Multitasking in PHP ♥
Alireza Rahmani Khalili gives us this well written introduction to getting started using Gearman, the fast distributed task runner, from your PHP applications using the Gearman PHP extension, and even touches on using the worker API to write Gearman enabled jobs. If you think your project could do from running jobs out of band from the web service component (and nearly any project of a certain size does, eventually), then this is an great option, and Alireza's intro is a solid starting point.

Beyond Inheritance ♥
Another brilliantly well written and clear article from Anthony Ferrara, this time on the topic of the use-cases for using traditional inheritance, versus composition with traits and abstract classes (to provide implementation and contract in loosely-coupled components). He describes it far better than I could, so go read, even if you think you know everything there is to know about OOP I always find I come away from Anthony's articles with something new to chew over.

Carica Chip 101 - Controlling An LED With PHP ♥
I previously featured Thomas Weinert's astounding project to do Arduino hardware control from PHP, by first creating a non-blocking IO library, an implementation of the Firmata protocol used to communicate with the microcontroller in the Arduino, and finally this culmination of his efforts, a PHP powered web server that controls an LED on the 'druino. *claps* Well done, sir.

A Peek At Aura v2 -- Aura.Dispatcher ♥
Paul M. Jones details the process, both thought and practical, involved in extracting the Aura v2 Aura.Dispatcher package from three different v1 packages that handled dispatch of some variety, from URL routing, to CLI param parsing/passing, and internal method invocation. This is a perfect example of deduplification, decoupling and refactoring, with a healthy dose of future proofing and API scaling when he discusses the API for how the Dispatcher can be used from both a micro-framework or fullstack-framework.

PHP 2.0: A Review in Retrospect ♥
Melissa Beth wrote this lovely, and in many places tongue-in-cheak, retrospective of the nearly forgotten PHP/FI 2.0's manual. That pretty much sets you up for the whole piece, if you can't stand even the most well natured of prods at your language of choice you'd better look away, because let's face it if you ever used 2.x or 3.x like I had the chance to, you know there were some massive warts. As Rasmus most famously stated "It was never intended to go beyond my own private use."

Open Source Mapping with PHP and MongoDB ♥
A neat little tutorial by Ryan Jarvinen on using Red Hat's OpenShift PaaS with PHP and MongoDB to do some cool geospatial hacking, in the example he grabs some open US National Parks data, parses it, pushes it into MongoDB complete with geo data, and quickly gets a simple web app up and running to display the data on a nice map. You can also see a live running demo, and fork the code on GitHub.

Symfony2 - Service Data Caching Using Annotations ♥
A cool little Symfony2 bundle and write up by Steven Lewis over at Epiphany, which simplifies the caching of data from API calls, using a clever combination of Symfony2's service tagging system, compiler passes, proxy classes and the Reflection API to override service calls at runtime based on phpDoc annotations and provide returned data from a cache if present or from the upstream API if not. Nicely done.

Array manipulation in PHP, the correct way ♥
An easy to digest post from Mike Curry to round off things. This one is most likely teaching many of you to suck eggs, but if you weren't aware of some of the more functional ways to do array manipulation in PHP then Mike covers them here.

Laravel Weekly ♥ ♥
Last but not least I wanted to give some space over to fellow weekly I discovered recently, from the team behind the Laravel community portal, Laravel Weekly is a great little weekly mailer with links and info for one of my favourite frameworks. Their GitHub repo is worth a look as they keep all their past issues not only in the final/sent HTML, but also in the original markdown, nice.


Projects

Hawk ♥
A nicely made implementation of the modern HTTP authentication scheme, hawk.

composer-script-utils ♥
This package provides, as yet, 3 very handy utility methods for working with paths inside a Composer script, and providing interactive updating of PHP INI config params.

iniscan ♥
One of my favourite utilities of late, by the infamous phpdeveloper.org man himself Chris Cornutt. iniscan scans (as well as showing with formatting) a PHP INI config file with a set of rules, and highlights any possible security flaws to deprecated options or bad practices. Invaluable.

samsui ♥
A handy (in some situations) utility with a very clever name. It provides a factory API for generating a tonne of objects with preconfigured attributes/fields, e.g. for auto-generating test data.

Flysystem ♥
A filesystem abstraction library that allows you to use a common API for interacting with "files and directories/paths" while swapping and changing underlying vendor drivers, from the filesystem, to FTP, S3 and Dropbox. It's under active development, has a very nice API, and something I think many projects could benefit from using.

PHP-VCR ♥
Based on Ruby's vcr gem, and similar to packages like nock in Node.js, this wonderful library allows you stop writing out mocked external services. Just stop. Instead you make real API calls, record them with VCR, and have the calls "played back" (I hope don't stretch the tape, zing) in your tests. Magic.

item.title: Issue #20 for Tuesday the 29th of October 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

Issue #20 for Tuesday the 29th of October 2013

Episode V The Newsletter Strikes Back

Well hellooooo there.
Before you say anything, I know, he doesn't call, he doesn't tweet, he certainly hasn't emailed (since May).
I could give you a laundry list of excuses, or instead I'll tell you that that is ending now, that the original PHP Weekly is back baby, back to stay, and back with a bang.

Starting with this issue PHP Weekly is as community centred and driven as a curated mailing list can be, if you want to see something in here, or more of something, tell me, work with me, we'll make it happen.

The repository for the website/archive/scripts are still freely available and open source, but also now includes the MailChimp email template used to send out issues, as well as even being installable via Composer for extra giggles. You can even file a GitHub issue with suggestions and bugs about the list.

(CodeConnexx && The Big Giveaway)



As part of the big PHP Weekly reboot we have lots of freebies to give away to readers, but one potential gift is up for grabs for anyone, a free ticket and help towards travel/accommodation for one person to amazing CodeConnexx being held 8th-9th November in Maastricht in the Netherlands.
Organised by the great people from PHPWomen, featuring an awesome line up of speakers, and boasting a unique 50/50 split of tech talks and soft topics to balance your mind.

If you would love to attend but can't make it due to finances, or you know someone you believe deserves the opportunity then please fill in in this form with your details and why you think you should be given the scholarship. (Or @CodeConnexx, if you think you can persuade in 140 chars that is).

For everyone else there is still time to get your ticket for CodeConnexx, and if you'd like 10% off then just use this link, what are you waiting for?

If that's not your cup of tea I have the following items to give away for free:
  1. 1 Personal License of JetBrains PhpStorm
  2. 2 copies of Cal Evan's new micro-book Signaling PHP
For a chance to win one of these prizes just email me expressing your interest in one or both prize types and I'll announce the randomly selected winners in a couple of weeks.

I also have hundreds of PHP Weekly stickers to give away, so if you want one (or if you want a few for your office or local user group) just email me your address.

News & announcements

Updates one and two on php.net
Two quick updates (because you know, they were a little busy) covering the attacks and infiltration of php.net, with a bonus tweet today proclaiming that git.php.net is back up in read and write mode, w00t.
Stay tuned for a full postmortem.

Wanted: New Emacs PHP Mode Maintainer ♥
Maintainer of PHP Mode Eric JM Ritz wishes to step down from being the main maintainer of the project, he doesn't wish to give it up completely, he just no longer feels has the time to be a driving force behind it. Do you use PHP Mode? Are you an emacs-head? Fancy pushing forward with a well established and liked project? Then get in touch with him, or reply to the GitHub ticket.

Audiovisuals

Google App Engine for PHP with PhpStorm (video and tutorial)
A guest blog post, on the Google Platform Blog, by Maarten Balliauw, Technical Evangelist at JetBrains, creator of the excellent PhpStorm IDE. In his post Maarten not only goes into detail about how to integrate PhpStorm with Google App Engine for PHP, but there's a handy dandy video that shows you just where and what to click to get going.

Signaling PHP (book)
The prolific Cal Evans has a new micro-book out which if you're at all into using PHP via the CLI, you'll want to check out right now, thuroughly covering the use and use case of POSIX process control signals.

PHP Town Hall Episode 14 - Ship Like a Candian, Eh? (audio podcast)

PHP Town Hall Episode 15 - Joomla, PHP-FIG and PSR-4 (YouTube video)

Articles

Symfony2 components overview: EventDispatcher ♥
ServerGrove's Raul Fraile discusses a favourite design pattern of mine: the mediator, and Symfony2's EventDispatcher is one of the better decoupled implementations. Raul goes through a few examples, as well as discussing using an event subscriber instead of a listener. This is one of those patterns which is gaining traction all across PHP with increased easier use of callbacks and anonymous functions in general.

php7 Interview With Michael Wallner A Full-Time Core PHP Developer – Try To Understand How Things Work & Why They Work That Way ♥ ♥
Khayrattee Wasseem returns with an excellent interview with a PHPc luminary, this time Michael Wallner, who is most recently known for being one of the few developers employed full time by a company (SmugMug) to work on PHP "core". A good interview all round, with lots of solid advice from Michael, and some great insight to what being employed full time to work on an open source project is actually like.

PHP extension writing ♥
Mikko Koppanen, maintainer of many popular extensions such as imagick and php-zmq, shares a note about writing extensions, with a pointer to a sample extension project he has started containing many of the tips and tricks he's gathered, called extsample.

What I took home from ZendCon 2013 ♥
This post from Zend Framework aficionado Michelangelo van Dam covers the amazing time he and many others were treated to this year at ZendCon 2013, from the awesome workshops, to astounding announcements (hellooooo Apigility), high quality talks and of course..the swag. Bless the swag.

Is ORM abstraction a pipe dream? ♥
David Adams gives us this well made write up of his adventures attempting to implement the repository pattern as an easily swappable wrapper around multiple ORMs. Using Doctrine, Propel and Eloquent as the base libraries for his after much wrangling around various APIs and methods, he concludes that while it probably is possible, it's definitely not something that's easily doable as a weekend side project. In the comments Matthieu Napoli makes the good point that the 3 libraries use different ORM patterns, e.g. the Data Mapper pattern, Active Record, and a mixture of the two, which increases the complexity involved in creating an abstraction.

Symfony benchmark using HHVM ♥
Alessandro Tagliapietra published the results from some basic benchmarks running two sample apps (a simple Symfony2 app, and a script to generate fibonachi sequences), using Facebook's HipHopVM (HHVM), PHP 5.4 (+/- APC) and PHP 5.5 (+ OPCache). Some of the results may surprise you, with a simple Symfony app being run much faster by PHP 5.5 with the excellent (formerly Zend) OPCache built in, even over HHVM, but while doing anything the actually uses CPU/memory (okay, it's just a fibonachi generator, but it's something) HHVM comes into it's own, with the JIT kicking in and speeding up certain ops. Read the comments for more discussion of what the results actually mean in real terms.


Projects

ixa-wordpress-core ♥
This is a well maintained and up to date fork of Wordpress with Composer support and available for install from Packagist so you can keep Wordpress maintained like any other dependency in your project, at least until the official patch is decided on and merged.

Fresque ♥
A cool little command line util for managing php-resque workers and queues, and it seems to even allow you to control regular resque workers/queues.

JsonpCallbackValidator ♥
A simple yet amazingly useful idea, this validator checks the content of a JSON-P callback (e.g. a JavaScript callback that will be called with a JSON payload on return to a click) and fails validation if any attempt to run extra code is detected (e.g. an XSS attack).

IcecaveStudios / collections ♥
A collection of..erm..collections, that is collection data types such as lists, queues, maps, sets, etc. based on the C#/.NET collections module, and expanding on the slightly lacking implementations found in the SPL.

3v4l.org ♥
An olde-but-goodie that comes in handy every now and again. Ever want to easily test some code in different versions of PHP? How about over 90 versions? In one go? Via the web? Try it out, but remember not to put anything confidential in those little textareas.

item.title: Issue #19 for Monday the 27th of May 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

Issue #19 for Monday the 27th of May 2013

The original

Back after another two week hiatus (sorry about this, traveling across Europe, giving talks, and preparing for a launch while still being a husband and dad can be a bit demanding).
Lots of news, articles and projects to get through from the past couple of weeks, activity across the PHP community seems to be hotting up nicely for summer.
 
I've talked about Gittip before, and indeed all the little hearts in this newsletter lead to Gittip pages for authors, as ever I encourage you to give contributions if you enjoy someones work (writing, coding, whatever), but more than this I encourage everyone to just sign up to Gittip and join in with the burgeoning PHP community that is forming there, which hasn't quite hit the mark for getting stats gathered about tips (come on guys, I'm sure we can push it over the mark).
 
I'm travelling again this weekend, this time to Berlin for DevOpsDays Berlin where I'll be speaking about scaling, team communication, culture and build systems on Tuesday. I'll have a few of the new shiny PHP Weekly stickers with me, so if you're at the event say hi and grab one.
If you're not at the event but you're in Berlin and fancy meeting up for a drink on Monday then just email or tweet me and I'm sure we can arrange something.

News & announcements

PHP 5.5.0RC1 released
This RC is a fix release for various bugs and memory leak, and in fact all releases up until 5.5 goes gold are as it's in feature freeze.

PHP 5.4.15 and PHP 5.3.25 really were released
There was some confusion when 5.4.15 and 5.3.24 were announced as a glitch in propagating the releases to the mirrors  stopped them from being available, but it's all fixed now so get 'em while they're hot.

Google made PHP available as a runtime on AppEngine
As others have said this week Google have finally made the language that powers 75% of the web available on their popular platform as a service, AppEngine, which previously was only capable of running Python and Java apps. See the Google I/O blog post for more details. Along with the announcement from the Goog, JetBrains announced the immediate release of a plugin which adds AppEngine support to the popular PHPStorm IDE, with built-in support to follow quickly.

Guzzle 3.5.0 released
One of the best HTTP/HTTPS client libraries for PHP around has got a major version bump, with memory and speed improvements, as well as scores of fixes and some refactoring. See the release notes for more.

Yii 2 Public Preview Available

New Aura logo, site and releases

Web & PHP Magazine May edition released

PHP NW 2013 announced, and the CFP is now open

Inovica launch another PHP weekly newsletter
First issue is available here, let me know what you think, anything they're doing better? Anything I'm doing better?

Audiovisuals

PHP Townhall episode 7
Regular hosts Phil Sturgeon ♥ and Ben Edmunds ♥ are joined by Ratcher creator and React co-creator Chris Boden ♥, and guess what, wouldn't you know they spend most of the time talking about WebSockets and non-blocking async/IO in PHP? Go figure. This is a fascinating episode as async/non-blocking APIs are one of my main areas of interest and I've wanted to know more about React and Ratchett for a while, and where better than the horses mouth, so to speak? The guys also talk about a few other bits and pieces, including the first ever PHP Townhall meetup, which while being held online didn't stop everyone from getting drunk and ranting for several hours. Good work.

Lately in PHP podcast episode 35
Regular hosts Manuel Lemos ♥ and Ernani Joppert ♥ talk about the need for better PHP internals docs, especially with the merge of the new shiny opcode cache, faster opcodes, interested rejected RFCs, and Manuel's recent article on version control systems.

Behat & Beautiful APIs talk slides
Slides from two talks by Tobias Schlitt, first on using Behat for behavioural driven development (held as a "webinar"), and the second a talk on API design given at the Cologne Symfony Usergroup.

Development, by the Numbers talk ♥
Slides and video from Anthony Ferrara's talk at DrupalCon Portland on development best practices and tooling. Great talk by a great guy, go and watch it.

PHP UK Conference 2013 - KEYNOTE

PHP UK Conference 2013 - KEYNOTE PANEL

Articles

PHP on Google App Engine – Quick First Review
A thorough write up on the new PHP Runtime on AppEngine, from what popular extensions are and aren't available, to some simple examples of getting an app up and running. If you've not had time to go over any of the docs or press releases from the Goog then this article makes for a pretty good primer.

Google App Engine, PHP and Silex. Setting up a Login Provider ♥
We're going to see lots more real world examples and reusable libraries just for GAE over the coming weeks, case in point Gonzalo Ayuso not only guides us through allowing logins through the GAE auth system, but also provides this full reusable Silex auth provider for it.

7php - A Chat About Adminer ♥
The prolific Khayrattee Wasseem did this follow up to his earlier interview with Jakub Vrana, this time discussing Jakub's database administration tool Adminer, a small and efficient alternative to the infamous phpMyAdmin.
Although I'm a command line guy myself so never really have use for these sorts of tools, but I know a lot of people out there prefer a more visual interface, or are restricted to how you can access a server, so this may be in handy, especially if like Jakub you're tired of copying the large phpMyAdmin codebase around.

7php - Know Thy PHP User Group Know The Leeds PHP User Group (LeedsPHP) ♥
Khayrattee also started this fantastic new feature on 7php taking a closer look at regional PHP user groups, interestingly starting with my geographically nearest group, LeedsPHP, which sadly I must admit despite being close and even having worked for a few years in Leeds I've never managed to make a meeting. However, this post, exploring the vibrancy of the strong user group and how they're managing to keep each meeting open and welcoming to everyone, has encouraged me to attend the next one!

Introduction to Vagrant/Puppet and introducing PuPHPet ♥
Vagrant is possibly one of my favourite tools of the last few years, and it is perfectly matched with configuration management tools like Puppet and Chef, however as Juan Treminio points out in this introductory post while vagrant itself is amazingly easy to use many people who start out trying to use Puppet to configure PHP (and the rest of the LAMP stack) in a VM can struggle, so he's created a great online GUI tool called PuPHPet to configure and generate a Vagrantfile and Puppet manifest to get you going. The code for PuPHet is also open and available on GitHub.

Cloning in PHP ♥
Giorgio Sironi explores the various ways in which a value can be a copied, including object instances which are cloned, and how cloning can be programmatically overridden for a class. Good overview if you're familiar with the different nuances beyond references and copy-on-write.

First PHP meetup by PHP Srbjia in Belgrade ♥
Miro Svrtan writes about the first ever PHP Srbjia PHP meetup (although with 250+ attendees and 4 talks it was more like a full conference), held in Belgrade on 28th of April. It looks like the day was an overwhelming success, and as Miro says it seems to be something the PHP community over there really needs, and it's very good to see community organised events like these take off.

Composer and PSR-0: Friends, Not Relatives ♥
Phil Sturgeon clears up a lot of confusion people have over the relationship between Composer and PSR-0, covering in detail (and his usual sarcastic wit) each common misconception and the technical reasons for why something might be (if indeed it is that way).

Static code analysis tools for PHP ♥
This well written article by Christopher Louis Martinez covers the wealth of static code analysis tools for PHP that allow the analysis and detection of various code smells that could cause issues down the line, even if it's just maintainability from badly formatted code.
Christopher also makes a good argument for the case that "good code" should be statically analysable, and that an inability to do this can be a code smell by itself.

Improve PHP session cookie security ♥
A quick but useful post by Simon Holywell covering a few of the INI/runtime options PHP provides to help armour a session from various attacks.

Compiling PHP 5.5 From Scratch ♥
A great write up by Brandon Savage detailing configuring and compiling 5.5, while we wait for the release to go gold and make it's way into various package managers; although his instructions are for a Debian based Linux system (such as Ubuntu) it shouldn't be too difficult to follow the same steps on another other nix-like.

#phpuceu ♥ ♥
Ole Michaelis and Soenke Ruempler attended the 2nd PHP Unconference in Europe, and had a fantastic time by the looks of it. They detail some of the adhoc talks they went on throughout the weekend, and great discussions. I love the fact that most of the unconference took place outside in the early summer weather (which has been sadly lacking this side of the atlantic, even in Berlin where the event took place).

Zend Framework 2 – Hydrators, Models and the TableGateway Pattern ♥
Matthew Setter shows us how to implement the hydrator, date mapper and table gateway patterns with Zend Framework 2, prsenting a very nice solution for decoupling your models from the datasource, right down to how fields are mapped (if required). There is some discussion in the comments that is worth checking out as this seems a hot topic in ZF2 at the moment, and the example Matthew provides is a great starting point to wet your lips on.

New in Symfony 2.3: Small things matter 
Symfony grand pubah Fabien Potencier goes over some of the many many small but exciting changes in Symfony 2.3.

Functional Testing to Improve Quality Assurance (part 1) ♥
A good high level view by Andy Podner of what functional testing is, as opposed to unit testing, complete with handy racecar analogy, and a brreakdown of benefits to doing functional testing alongside unit testing.

Code complexity and clean code ♥
Testing and clean code maestro Brandon Savage wrote up this excellent description, with practical examples, of cyclomatic complexity, and NPath complexity, two formal definitions and metrics for measuring code complexity. The two methodologies go hand in hand when doing automated code complexity analysis and a good understanding of them should place most developers in a good position to at the very least rethink the complexity and clealiness of their code.

Simplest PHP Generator Example ♥
Lorna Jane Mitchell really likes generators, which is great as everyone should, generators are awesome and she goes over a simple example (in fact the simplest example) of a generator as you will be able to use them in PHP 5.5, which she backs up with a description of what makes them great and the practical cases when you'd want to use one (pretty much any time you want to use an Iterator, but with less code complexity).

Survived php tek 2013 ♥
A tantalising write up of php|tek 2013 by this year's uncon organiser Michelangelo van Dam, including some of his favourite talks and highlights from other events such as the Hacktathon (kudos to Lorna Jane Mitchell and joind for lots of pull requests).

Understanding HTTP Digest Access Authentication 
Sean Hudgston goes step by step through using HTTP Digest Authentication in PHP, which in my experience can be a bit of a pain in the posterior so good to see more how to's on this for those few instances when you need to handle Digest auth at the application level.

A Conversation About Testing in PHP ♥ ♥
Chris Hertjes and Ed Finkler of /dev/hell fame shoot the breeze about PHP testing tools, methodologies and just why Chris weeps for the future.If you're struggling with any testing concepts, or like Ed don't like PHPUnit very much, read through this and you just made glean some insight. At the very least it's an amusing read. ;-)

Full Test Coverage is Impractical ♥
In this quick post Anna Filina restates a view I've held for many years: "full" test coverage of an application not only means very little in many cases, but is actually impossible (for some values of impossible, i.e. very bloody hard). Not only this the tests created tend to mean very little and provide a false feeling of protection.


Projects

Lurker ♥
A promising library for Symfony2 resource objects that allows you to subscribe to a watcher and receive events when a watched resource changes (or in most cases a certain method is called).

Mondrian ♥
An extremely cool tool for performing static code analysis of a project, along with methods for applying graph theory to code, and generate pretty visualisations of different metrics.

RMT ♥ ♥
A tool for managing relases in a project, allowing for the use of templates to update changelogs, VCS tags and more.

doc-renderer ♥
A pure PHP library for rendering Markdown and RST as HTML.

fabricius ♥
A Jekyll like static site generator with a nice API and the usual goodies (markdown support, content querying etc.)

boris ♥
A small REPL for PHP, written in PHP itself, with some nice features. Very interested in this as I've used Facebook's phpsh REPL for some time, after greatly missing the REPLs from Python and Ruby when working with PHP.

Nyan Cat PHPUnit Result Printer ♥
Ever wanted a Nyancat to dance across your terminal displaying your unit test results? Of course you have, why wouldn't you? Well here you go.

item.title: Issue #18 for Sunday the 5th of May 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

Issue #18 for Sunday the 5th of May 2013

if (typeof($world->yield(), 'lemon')) { ... }

The stickers I promised people should be on the way now, via various postal systems, and I've got a second batch on order with the new logo which should hopefully get here by the end of the week.
I'll be speaking at Atmosphere 2013, and DevOpsDays Berlin, so if you're attending either and you'd like one of the new PHP Weekly stickers just hit me up.

One other thing I forgot to mention, as well as subscribing by email or following @1stvamp or @phpweekly on Twitter, you can now subscribe to new weeklies via RSS, if that's your thing. (You may also be interested in the script I use to generate the feed from archived HTML pages.)

If you find PHP Weekly useful please consider supporting me via Gittip ♥.

News & announcements

Symfony 2.3.0 Beta 1 released
Symfony 2.3 is nearly here, with a whole shed load of features and changes, so if you use Symfony or rely on components that do (increasingly more frameworks and individual components do) you might want to get testing.

phpMyAdmin 4.0.0 released
v4 of phpMyAdmin has gone gold, with lots of bug fixes rolled in, one of the biggest differences in 4 is that it no longer uses the well known split iframe interface and instead uses a single HTML document with a JavaScript driven tree UI.

php|architect April issue out
The April edition of php|a is out, this month featuring mostly articles about security, from password hashing done right to securing file upload. the team at musketeers.me are also running a survey to access which format people prefer the magazine in as they've switched back to the classic vertical style as an experiment.

Articles

An Introduction to Ctype Functions ♥
David Shirey simply covers various uses of the ctype extension for validating characters in a string.

Using RabbitMQ in Unit Tests ♥
A very clever write up by Alvaro Videla about how they uses the RabbitMQ pre-built nightly (currently only available for OS X, but this will hopefully change) to untar and run an out of the box instance of RabbitMQ with which to run their unit tests against. Very clever alternative to mocking out your RabbitMQ provider classes, or if you really want to test that part against a real component.

Testing Smells - Try/catch ♥
Chris "grmpyprogrammer" Hartjes gives us this great piece on why using try/catch blocks in your unit tests is nearly always bad practice, especially with inbuilt functionality in PHPUnit for handling exceptions as part of a test.

Serializing Data Like a PHP Session ♥
A quick piece by Josh Adell on serialising arbitrary data to/from the format used by PHP for storing session data, as the builtin functions session_encode and session_decode will only work directly with the $_SESSION superglobal. Josh provides some userspace functions to get around this that work by temporarily swapping data in $_SESSION.

WordPress 10th Anniversary Blogging Project ♥
Dougal Campbell kicks off discussion about WordPress's 10 year anniversary (on the 27th May) by writing about his history during the project's timeline, and encouraging others to the same. Use the hashtag #wp10 on Twitter to get in on the action.

Working With Dates and Times in PHP ♥
A great write up by Ravi Gill on various techniques for working with datetimes in PHP using the DateTime, DatePeriod and DateInterval classes that ship with 5.2 and above.

Use RouteMatch in Zend Framework 2 For Easy Routing ♥
Matthew Setter wrote up how to use the ZF2 RouteMatch, Router and Request APIs to dynamically change the parameters and filters used by Zend Paginator instance, displaying customised results in a paginated list, with a re-render.

Crop and Resize Images with ImageMagick ♥
A nice little tutorial by Sandeep Panda on using the ImageMagick extension to resize user uploaded images, for example automatically resizing a profile image, or even taking a user selected crop size (he covers using one of the many jQuery plugins to allow the user to select a crop size from their selected image). I would also like to note that while this is a great technique for a low impact service, e.g. for profile pictures that don't get set very often, if you are planning on doing something more image heavy (e.g. a photos site that might hit the cropping or resize functionality quite a lot) you should invest in offloading the image resizing and cropping to an out-of-request task system. As Sandeep mentions you should also put some time into making sure the file upload portion of the app is secure and has sane limits.

Functionally Testing Your Application Using Mink ♥
A great article by Konstantin Kudryashov on using the Mink browser emulation/instrumentation library to create functional/integration tests, covering hooking up to Silex using silex-mink, using it with PHPUnit tests rather than Behat, and getting the most interface/API coverage out of your tests. The Selenium driver is covered, but there are plenty of drivers available for different engines.

Testing and Contributing with Composer Packages ♥
A typically well written and thorough guide by Phil Sturgeon on contributing to PHP packages that use Composer, from getting a package installed locally with dependencies, to testing your patch and going through with a pull request. We need lots more of this in the community to get the present ecosystem of Composer packages fleshed out and more mature

7php Interview With Jakub Vrana Co-Author Of The Official PHP Manual ♥
Khayrattee Wasseem is back with another great interview with a PHP community luminary, this week Jakub Vrana (♥) is up, known for his work on the PHP Manual, Adminer and NotORM, covering the usual early days with PHP, how he's involved in the PHP community, to PHP hints and tips (especially some favourites from his book), his involved with the PHP manual and more.

How to gracefully handle cache expiration ♥
A good write up by Aleksey Korzun on being smarter with your caching, focusing on using the Memcache extension with memcached for caching some model objects, and solving common high load issues such as the thundering herd problem with techniques like wrapping your objects with shorted cache time and delaying cache returns out of the request cycle to avoid response delays caused by execution.


Projects

arrch
ORM-style queries for arrays, which might be just what you need if you're working with large and/or complex data structures imported into an Array.

ClosestDate
A helper utility that provides APIs for finding dates close to a given date (or list or dates), handy for calendar functionality and user scheduling.

Duct
A stream based JSON library which allows you to parse and utilise JSON data incrementally, such as when streamed from a network connection.

graze/event
An event based pub/sub library, allows you to subscribe to events by simply implementing a specific method or set of methods.

item.title: Issue #17 for Sunday the 28th of April 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

Issue #17 for Sunday the 28th of April 2013

Trying something new

As an experiment this week, inspired by PyCoder Weekly, I'm adding Gittip ♥ links (if there is one) for any article and project authors, and I highly encourage people to give some micropayment goodness out to fellow developers who give up their time and energy to give us all great value writing and code.

I already use Gittip myself to give some money back to project leaders every week whom I get so much value from.

Of course nothing has changed, there's no advertising here, just an extra link you don't need to click if you don't want to, and I won't mention it again.
If you think this is a good idea let me know via the usual channels and I'll continue doing it. :-)

News & announcements

PHP 5.5 beta 4 released
A few bug fixes, which is both promising and expected so late in the beta release cycle, it looks like we're on track for the release candidate on May 9th. Now is the time to get testing if you've not begun already. See the news file for more info.

Elefant 1.3.5 released
Another bugfix and feature packed beta release from this extremely promising CMS. A key new features is the addition of role based access control which is a definite must for any serious CMS, especially for enterprise use, and the Elefant devs seem to have gone about it in the right way. See the changelog for more info.

 

PSR-0, PSR-1, PSR-2 and PSR-3 translated into simplified Chinese

Audiovisuals

PHP Podcast episode 2 ♥
Zend's Joe Stagner is back with another episode in this interesting new podcast series. This time he is joined by another Zender, Adam Culp, to talk about the PHP community, how Zend is trying to engage more with the overall community, differences between freelancing and working for a company like Zend, and more.

/dev/hell episode 31
The infamous Chris Hartjes (♥) and Ed Finkler (♥) return to shoot the breeze about anything and everything they can, covering the usual topics of PHP, JavaScript, testing, conferences, and frameworks. Listen out for talk about frameworkless frameworks (as Rasmus would put it) and lightweight frameworks.

Cloud Out Loud - Future of PHP: Drupal
David Shafik talks to well known core Drupal-ers Angela Byron, Dries Buytaert and Larry Garfield to talk about one of the most popular CMS-come-frameworks on the web today, what's changed in Drupal 8 and what is to come.

Build RESTful ZF2 Applications ♥
The slides from Matthew Weier O’Phinney's webinar (free to watch, but requires registration) on building RESTful web apps with Zend Framework 2, Matthew starts with a good overview of the principles of REST itself before launching right into practical examples.

Articles

Simple logging of ZF2 exceptions ♥
Rob Allen wrote this nice little piece on using Zend\Log along with ZF2's event listening to create and attach an application logger that catches your exceptions for you. Very neat and possibly useful even if you're not running a pure ZF2 app.

Performance benchmark of popular PHP frameworks ♥
A great speed comparison (requests/sec), by Lukasz Kujawa, of thirteen of the most popular PHP frameworks. As Lukasz says it is incredibly difficult comparing apples for apples when it comes to frameworks but he's tried to level the playing field as much as possible with a basic project that uses the standard configurations for each. The great take away from this isn't the unsurprising news that Slim is fast, being a microframework, but the finishing paragraph about the real purpose of frameworks, to boost development. Speed can always be boosted through other methods.

Testing Laravel Controllers ♥
A great and very thorough step by step guide by Jeffrey Way on testing Laravel controllers in isolation. As well as testing Jeffrey covers refactoring your application core using inversion of control, making testing extremely clean and easier to do.

Sandboxing Untrusted Code With PHPSandbox ♥
Elijah Horton goes through using his own PHPSandbox library to test "untrusted PHP code" in a sandbox from the executing system PHP, which is especially good if for some reason you need to execute user provided code (something you should usually try to avoid at all costs but there are some use cases, like with sites like ScraperWiki), I've covered PHSandbox box briefly before but I'll say again that it's a very cool project, and things get really interesting with the ability to override entire functions in the executed code, including builtins, with your own.

PHP is meant to die
An interesting piece on the suitability of PHP for long running processes. Before we get into the fact that actually yes PHP can be perfectly used for long running processes, especially since a lot of GC cleanup was added in 5.x, I'll say now that I agree with the fact that PHP's basic model is that it is optimised for a single short lived request. Rasmus has stated before that he sees that as PHP's strength in being horizontally scalable with a shared nothing architecture, and afaik every feature, change and optimisation to PHP is developed with that in mind. Another point that is dead on is that we shouldn't really do background tasks inside requests, even though there are tricks to do this and a few frameworks implement in their core, it's a bad idea and should be avoided (disclaimer: I recently did exactly this too.)

The Epic Tale of Moving to HipHop
tuenti's Daniel Paneda (♥) made this excellent write up on their move to Facebook's alternative PHP implementation HipHop, which you may remember statically compiles your PHP to C code (which is then compiled to a native binary), and can deliver significant speed advantages over cached PHP opcode interpretation. Lots of details here on what they had to change and why, mostly dropping newer PHP features and APIs due to not being implemented in HipHop yet, and also the parts of HipHop they improved themselves to get going. I'd love to hear a similar story for HipHop VM, anyone out there done it in a production env?

20 Point List For Preventing Cross-Site Scripting In PHP ♥
Pádraic Brady wrote this handy twenty point todo list that covers what you either need to do or at least consider in order to protect yourself against XSS attacks. Some good points here, and while yes a lot have pointed out that at the end of the day "don't trust anyone, armour everything" is a succinct way of putting it these finer points will help most people get there if they don't know where to start.

Bonnes pratiques Symfony2 : notre condensé! ♥
This langue française piece by Thomas Jarrand is a great list of take-away best practices from Symfony Live 2013 for developing with Symfony2. Some of these are excellent points for any developer to take on board, not just Symfony ones

Write secure templates with Latte ♥
A great write up by Jiří Pudil on how to use the Latte templating library, that comes as part of the Nette framework, to write highly secured templates for applications. They're secured via context aware escaping, with macros and helpers that make not just writing code easier but also allow you to improve escaping by providing increased context. I'd not come across Latte before, and while it's very similar to Twig in many regards, it does have a few nice unique features, especially in the automatic nature of it's escaping.


Projects

morafabio/vagrant-php-development-box ♥
Another base Vagrant project loaded with a base viewee configuration to create a reusable box, as well as Chef cookbooks to install the usual LAMP tools you could want in a dev VM.

ZF2 Restful Module Skeleton ♥
A very nicely written and full featured base ZF2 project to get you going writing a RESTful app with the ZF2 RestfulController package.

Toro ♥
A richly featured yet extremely slim routing framework for PHP, which has one of the nicest APIs I've seen in one of the multitude of loosely coupled route libraries now available.

Doctrine Annotations ♥
Doctrine famously uses annotations embedded in the docblock for methods and properties to perform extra runtime metadata handling, such as database operations in different contexts. This is the library that performs the docblock parsing behind annotations so if you fancy doing something similar yourself, here you go.

SetnGeti ♥
Speaking of docblock annotations this library does something similar by automatically adding accessor and mutator methods for properties if you add @get/@get to the property's docblock.

item.title: Issue #16 for Saturday the 20th of April 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

Issue #16 for Saturday the 20th of April 2013

Back in black (and purple)

Aaaand we're back, bit of a hiatus there due to a busy schedule (like launching a new beta) but hopefully all good now.

PHP Weekly now has a shiny new logo (and sticker when I print more) curtesy of great guys at CGSmith.net. Let me know what you think of it.

With any luck I'll be announcing some awesome news next week, so stay tuned.

In other news if you'd like to see me talk about web development, scaling and devops I'll be giving talks at Atmosphere 2013 and DevOpsDays Berlin 2013, both in May.

News & announcements

PHP 5.5 beta3 released
Mostly a bug fix release in the ramp up to 5.5 going gold, see the NEWS file for more.

PHP 5.4.14 and PHP 5.3.24 released
Mostly a bug fix release encompassing memory leaks are type handling, which also means there's very little reason not to update, so off to the package managers! See the ChangeLog for more.

Zend Framework 2.1.5 released
Monthly maintenance release of ZF2 right on schedule, which also includes a tonne of improvements from last months documentation push.

Symfony 2.2.1 released
Quite a few stability and security fixes rolled out with 2.2.1, so you definitely want to bump if you're using Symfony 2.2 directly or using components which do.

Laracasts.com launched
A great new site for screencasts on developing with the Laravel framework.

Symfony Live Portland 2013 schedule published

PHP The Right Way translated to Deutsch

eZ Publish 2013.4 released

Drupal 7.22 released

Joomla 3.1 beta 4 released

Laravel 4 beta 4 released

 

Audiovisuals

PHP Town Hall episode 6
Another great episode from regular hosts Phil Sturgeon and Ben Edmunds, joined by PHP celebs Paul M. Jones, Anthony Ferrera, and regular guest and fellow snake charmer Zack Kitzmiller. With 50% of the room being PHP-FIG members they mostly talk about Paul's recent PSR-X proposal to improve the PSR-0 package loading standard, and also about the wider significance of the PHP-FIG's work for the whole of the PHP community.
As usual contains swears, actually lots of swears, so avoid if you don't like that sort of thing.

Lately in PHP podcast episode 34
I'm afraid I haven't had a chance to listen to the latest episode so I'm effectively restating what it says on the site: regular hosts Manuel Lemos and Cesar Rodas talked about a better PHP voting process, new releases, updating PHP with minimal downtime and "how brilliant are some developers for creating pure PHP components that overcome PHP limitations without upgrading to a newer PHP version."

Articles

Traits are Static Access
A very thorough tear down by Benjamin Eberlei on why using traits to extend your classes can be just as hazard for code maintainability and testing as using tightly coupled static methods everywhere. He argues that traits create similar code smells to lots of static method use and have issues such as not being mockable and providing global state. An interesting point of view on traits that I hadn't considered before and I'd be interested to hear more peoples opinions. Avoid them completely? Or find better ways to use?

Salt, Hash and Store Passwords Securely with Phpass
A simple walkthrough by Mike Dalisay on how to use phpass to correctly hash and storage passwords in your app. Mike covers the basics here with some simple code examples, so I'll just point out that phpass also provides many other utilities for edge cases in password use so you'll probably want to look at the docs, and Ryan Chouinard has a nice Composer package you can use.

About Symfony: Stability over Features
Core Symfony maintainer Fabien Potencier has written up what he thinks should be the main focus for Symfony2 development over the coming months, yes you guessed it, stability. Stability means a few different things to different people however, so Fabien includes a concise list of what that means to him and which parts of Symfony need some stability lovin'.

Use Dice for Simplified PHP Dependency Injection
Tom Butler wrote this nice introduction to the Dice DI library, covering how Dice's rule based API is different to how other contains work mostly with factory classes. Tom goes on to show some simple applications for this in your code, with the goal being the ability to completely swap and change any internal dependency without altering APIs or large refactors.

Define: Functional, Unit and Integration Tests
Anna Filina describes the different types of tests we all hear about every day, from what makes them different to why you would use one over the other in different situations, and most importantly why you probably need all three to correctly cover testing a full stack. 

Diving into Behat
A good write up by Giorgio Sironi on the ins and outs of using Behat to unit test your application using behavioural driven development as a guiding principal. He provides a particularly helpful list of situations when Behat probably isn't the right choice before going on to explain writing behaviour specifications for an application, and using those specs to write actual tests, as well as caveats for ensuring tests don't become hard to maintain.

Enqueue Symfony’s process components with PHP and ZeroMQ
A great piece by Gonzalo Ayuso on combining the ZeroMQ socket library with the React non-blocking event library for PHP, to create an asynchronous queue of Symfony process comonents. A clever little example with a video showing it in action. As pointed in the article and comments React isn't necessary in his example as it is actually blocking with the use of blocking ZMQ messages, but it is possible to make this non-blocking with some work and using an event loop makes the concepts slightly easier to grasp.

Generating One-Time Use URLs
Angela Hinkler gives us this tutorial on generating one time use URLs, like those often used for resetting your password, or for sending confidential information to a contact without risk of someone else being able to open it later. A nice example of doing the grunt work for handling a URL like this, but as pointed out in the comments if you do this yourself please use a library like RandomLib to generate the tokens as those used in the examples are susceptible to timing attacks.

Do we need a framework for that? Or hurry up PHP-FIG
Phil Bennett thinks the real secret sauce provided by the PHP-FIG is in providing common interfaces for components between frameworks, to allow more decoupling and more test driven practices, just like PSR-3 does for logging, and wants to see more of this. Difficult to argue with that to be honest..but people will anyway. :-)

Deploying PHP applications with Phing
A very thorough and well put together rundown by Lukasz Kujawa on using Phing to build and deploy an entire application, with a real world example that goes from performing various file based tasks to more in-depth examples such as initialising a database and generating deployment configuration. I especially like the explanation of using and overriding properties to provide context specific deployment data, something people often miss with Phing that allows you to even do context switching based on environment.

Sitepoint: What Happened when we Talked PHP with the Experts
Sarah Hawk  sat down with tutor, speaker and author Lorna Mitchell to talk about her OO course and various topics spanning PHP development and the PHP community.

7php Interview With Manuel Lemos Founder Of PHPClasses.org
Another excellent interview from Khayrattee Wasseem with a PHP community A-Lister, this time Manuel Lemos of PHPClasses.org and Lately in PHP fame. They discuss Manuel's work with PHPClasses, his early years with PHP way back, daily development practices, and most interestingly for me the Brazilian PHP community and culture which has fostered great cooperation and spirit over the years.

Composer primer
This excellent primer by Dayle Rees covers the basics for not just building out your first package, but also some of the more trickier concepts of dependency management, autoloading and general command usage.

Automated backups to Google Drive with PHP API
Lukasz Kujawa goes step by step through using Google Drive as a backup location for general backups (such as file, data etc.), much like you would with Amazon S3 or Dropbox, from setting up an API account and using his cp2google library to power the backups.

Extending Twig Templates: Inheritance, Filters, and Functions
Rakhitha Nimesh wrote this concise tutorial on simply building filters and helper functions for your Twig templates by extending core filters and callables.

Is PSR-0 Shortsighted, or are you?
Phil Sturgeon wrote this reply to Tom Butler's PHP: PSR-0: Pretty Shortsighted, Really, which posited that there were various issues with PSR-0 autoloading. He goes blow by blow through each point with clear responses, as both as a developer and PHP-FIG member. The main sticking points seem to come down to confusion between what the PHP-FIG are trying to do (no they aren't "forcing standards" on anyone) and that PSR-0 != Composer. They seem like simple concepts by the crop up time and time again. Most people also don't seem to realise they can override autoloading in Composer if they want to define their own package structure.

Tom's PHP Commandments - Take heed
Tom Buck, living up to his site name of "Biased PHP" gives us this extremely biased list of nine DOs and DO NOTs, from things like avoiding variable variables for simplicity and clarity, to never using weak hashing for passwords or injecting variables directly into SQL strings. Some of these points are so opinionated I personally wouldn't always follow them to letter (e.g. never using CakePHP for a project, or Apache, both of which have had improvements in recent years that don't necessarily seem reflected in these "commandments"), but there are some great take-aways nonetheless.

Base Converting and Binary Operators
A great little primer by Timothy Boronczyk  on number bases and converting between bases using binary operators in PHP, not much more to say other than this is one of those things you may have forgotten from math classes or first year compsci, but you may require one day if working with numeric data, especially large data set exports from different systems.

PHPUnit vs. Phake cheatsheet
A great comparison of two of the major PHP mocking libraries, with direct examples for both for creating stubs, mocks and spies.

Reflection in PHP
A tutorial by Patkos Csaba on using reflection, or rather in this context meta-programming (which uses reflection) to inspect the properties of objects to build up APIs that don't rely on specific classes, object instances or even specific APIs to a degree, and only using some of the simpler parts of the Reflection API.

Your PHP site may not be secure
Thomas Lackemann reminds us of an old but always relevant "information leak" in the case of leaving expose_php turned on in your config which enables a special querystring to be called to display PHP info such as the version of PHP, credits and enabled modules, as well as exposing the PHP version as a HTTP header, which can both be disabled by setting "expose_php = off" in your PHP config.
Why is this a security issue? Allowing such info leakage allows a potential attacker to more quickly asses attacks that can be used against your server. Of course there always other examples of such options in your server of choice (e.g. Apache or Nginx) that can be disabled.

Interest for a PHP IDE Plugin
Subscriber and Sublime user Devon Weller is probing PHP developers and Sublime users to see if there's any interest in creating a full IDE-like plugin for Sublime that would provide full code introspection and completion for PHP such as the kind you you get in PhpStorm.

PHP Namespaces: Avoid use
Jason McCreary cautions against the use of the use keyword in PHP and advises using full namespace paths over aliases imports.
I'm not a particularly big fan of this myself, and I think if you find yourself in the position that aliasing an import into the local symbolspace can cause issues with no knowing what you're instancing at any one time and where that class originates from, I think you need to break up your namespace further, as such problems are a classic symptom of overloading your source files with class definitions.
I do heartily agree with the advice of being aware what exactly your imports are doing however and if you do have lots of conflicting class names across multiple namespaces you should stick to importing higher level namespaces not the classes themselves, as just avoiding use completely, especially large codebases is really throwing the baby out with the bath water.


Projects

Medoo
An extremely lightweight database ORM, with lots of backend support and rich featureset.

jamiefdhurst/vagrant-dev
A simple Vagrant environment that uses the shell based provisioning to setup a common PHP specific box.

Gitter
A simple and clean OO wrapper for common operations with git.

print_o
A very handy object graph visualizer for PHP for graphing dependencies between class instances. See some of the examples for a good idea what you can use this for.

openlss/lib-stream-wrapper
A lightweight wrapper around PHP's stream wrappers which provides an Interface for more easily building stream wrappers.

whoops
Taglined as "php errors for cool kids", whoops is a very nice debugging and exception handling library, which is similar to SaaS apps like New Relic or Sentry.

patch-installer
Rely on a dependency handled by Composer and need to patch it but don't want to maintain a full fork? patch-installer is an add-on for Composer that allows you to patch your Composer installed packages, while maintaining the data for the patch from your package JSON, with some limitations.

PHP types autoboxing
An implementation of SPL Types that allows you to wrap PHP scalar types with initial method calls and maintain your wrapped types (and their methods, metadata etc.) even after setting the variable to a different value.

ChromePhp
A PHP implementation of the Chrome debugging protocol used by the Chrome Logger extension which allows you to view server side debugging and logging information inside the Google Chrome developer tools right alongside your client side logs.

Nest
A very nice decorator util that allows wrap and call properties, methods and other "attributes" of nested objects using keys with a familiar array key/value notation. It's great to see more and more decorators like this crop up in PHP, like they have similarly in Python, Ruby and JavaScript.

Phinx
Phinx is an extremely powerful yet simple to use database migration framework, allowing you to migrate both schemas and data between different DB schemas, using either PHP or SQL itself.
