item.title: Issue #15 for Saturday the 30th of March 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #15 for Saturday the 30th of March 2013

Be excellent

I'm seriously considering setting the regular mailout day for PHP Weekly to Saturdays, given the past three issues and this one have all been Saturday releases.
Oh well, hopefully it gives you all something to look forward to when you get into the office Monday morning.

An update on the stickers: I haven't mailed them out yet but I will be doing in the next week, I've just been super busy, if anyone else would like any then drop me an email with your address as I'm probably going to do another batch soon (and may have an updated version of the sticker soon too, watch this space).

News & announcements

PHP 5.5 beta 2 released
Mostly bug fixes from beta 1, see the NEWS file for more details.

Help Ed "Funkatron" Finkler give his Open Sourcing Mental Illness talk EVERYWHERE
Ed has a wonderful talk addressing mental health issues in an honest and open way, which like many of us he has personally dealt with his whole life, and he'd like to present it to as many people as possible in as many places, so he's crowdfunding those efforts. The PHP community managed to band together and hit his target goal in the first 24 hours, but the more money we throw at him the more places like smaller events and user groups he'll be able to get to. Go go go!

Symfony 2.1.9 released
A few bugs in the 2.1 branch fixed, including some security issues, so if you rely on Symfony2 or use components which do get upgrading! You can see the changelog for more details.

MongoDB PHP Driver 1.3.6 released
This release allows commands to be run on secondaries if they can be, were as previously they would always be run on primaries.

phpMyAdmin 4.0.0-beta3 released
This looks to be a bugfix release in the 4.0 betas, no idea what's in it but if you're trying out the 4 series betas you should probably upgrade to this new one.

Elefant CMS 2 beta 4 released
The 4th beta release of this excellent CMS marks the 2.0 branch being feature complete, it's just bugfixes from here out, so if you're an Elefant user or want to give a new CMS a try, give it a looksie.

MODX Cloud to become “SiphonLabs”
One of the biggest commercial entities behind the MODX CMS is effectively spinning off into 2 groups, the current owner behind MODX, MODX LLC, and a new company called SiphonLabs who will continue to support the development of MODX as well as customers but also drive development of a cloud platform supporting use of MODX and it's components (and adoption of said platform). The other big news from this is that they'll be pushing on with Wordpress and possible Magento cloud hosting, which  brings a wider range of software to the table for existing customers as well as putting another big name Wordpress/[Magento?] SaaS/PaaS provider out there.

 

Audiovisuals

DC4C: Worst Case Scenario slides
Dr Keith Casey Jr's talk from Day Camp 4 Developers #5 all about avoiding problems with your presentation, mitigating issues that arise, or making the best of it when things go awry, from practicing and recording your presentation, to being prepared for technical difficulties, to the sort of things you just can't avoid. I'm still going through all the DC4C videos myself so can't comment on Keith's actual talk, but there's plenty of tips in the slides to help you out.

The PHPPodcast episode #1 – Cal Evans
Unfortunately can't comment on this maiden episode in the new (hopefully) regular PHPPodcast series, by Joe Stagner, but the first episode is an interview with Cal Evans who never fails to deliver when it comes to discussions about the PHP community and PHP itself, so recommended just for that.
Update: I've been listening along while writing this issue and the first episode is great! There's lots of backstory on changes in Microsoft's stance on PHP back in the day from Joe, Cal's views on the community of the years, and some interesting thoughts on the new relationship between mobile frontend development and backend development.

FLOSS Weekly episode #244 – CakePHP
Regular co-host Aaron Newcomb (covering for regular host Randal Schwartz) is joined by co-host Randi Harper. They interviewed CakePHP core dev Mark Story, discussing how CakePHP positions itself against other web frameworks, focussing as it does on convention over configuration, ease of installation and fast initial time to first app. Some good discussion about removing magic in CakePHP 2 for improved performance, security improvements and what Mark thinks sets Cake apart.

Becoming A Better Developer - Programming With Anthony
A short entry in this great series from Anthony Ferrara with a slightly different, more free form, format. He talks a little about possibly the greatest skill as an IT professional you can ever pick up and expand upon: how to figure out and problem and find resources. As Anthony puts it nobody will ever expect you to know everything, but you better know how to find it.

/dev/hell Podcast Episode 30: It's Episode 30, You Guys
Chris "GrmpyProgrammer" Hartjes and Ed "Funkatron" Finkler return with another eclectic Developer Hell episode, covering topics from JavaScript, to testing (of course), lots of JavaScript testing, speaking and Ed's aforementioned Open Sourcing Mental Health crowdfunding efforts.

Articles

If PHP Were British
A tongue-firmly-in-cheek what-if post by Dave Child supposes a new version of PHP taking on British mannerisms, politeness and old British Empire ideas of class. Funny stuff, and in case you fancy jumping on the HN bandwagon of calling this out as an American misunderstanding Anglo's, Dave is a fellow Brit.

7php Interview With Lineke Kerckhoffs-Willems Co-Founder Of ProTalk.me
Another excellent interview from our friend Khayrattee Wasseem with talented and omg-I-can't-believe-she-has-time-to-do-get-all-that-done Lineke Kerckhoffs-Willems, discussing her involvement with PHPwomen.org and ProTalk.me, as well as general topics such as tips for improving your PHP skills, time management and QA.

Where have all the core devs gone?
Lukas Kahwe Smith points out that the majority of core developers who got Symfony2 out the door are now primarily leading/involved with other projects, or have mostly fallen quiet, leaving lead maintainer Fabien Potencier to cover and prioritise (in secret, but by chance no purpose) all pull requests to Symfony, and decide what goes into new releases. With this break down of organisation around the project it means there's a lack of openness and clarity, and Lukas thinks a good solution to this would be to bring in the role of release manager, just like PHP core (and many other open source projects). Sounds like a good idea to me, Fabien isn't entirely convinced by all of Lukas' points but he fully on board with improving the situation, so watch this space.

Etsy: There and Back Again: Migrating Geolocation Data to GeoNames
John Marc blogged about how Etsy have improved their geolocation and location aware features by moving from a closed provider to the GeoNames open dataset, implementing internal services in PHP to consume/process this data and provide locality info based on various points. They have the code, for mapping this data to MySQL tables and performing geo queries on them, up on GitHub.

Abstraction In The Real World
A typically good post by Brandon Savage on not only the value of abstraction in your code, but lots of concrete examples of different types of abstraction showing how they actually help maintainable, flexibility and often comprehension.

Lukas Smith: For the very first time: Hello UK!
Another write up of the previously mentioned PHPNE, this time by Lukas Kahwe Smith, showing not only more evidence that it was a fantastic event, but also highlighting his favourite parts from talks, workshops, and talks down at the pub, with a predictably higher slant towards Symfony2 topics.

First Phing Plugin
Lorna Jane Mitchell goes over developing her first Phing plugin, from initial creation to usage. This is a topic I have quite a bit of experience with and Lorna nails this first steps guide very well, although I must admit one thing I'd like to see in a future post is how to effectively test Phing plugins, maybe I should just write it myself finally.

Pick PHP Requirements for Packages Responsibly
Phil Sturgeon gets right to the point with this post, arguing that it is incredibly irresponsible to release open PHP libraries, with a view for others to use them, that require new "shiny" features in 5.4 (and even 5.3) that actually add nothing to the library itself, the main example being using [] instead of arrays just because they look more awesomer, because then your library requires an entire upgrade of PHP to be used in another project, and by extension people need to be careful about the dependencies they choose for their projects for this same reason. He goes on to argue against the "but it boosts adoption of new PHP versions" fallacy, and to tell people to just write for an older version. I would add that this of course really only applies to open projects, if you're writing your companies business app in 5.4 because you have it on your servers and your team like the syntactical sugar, then bloody well have at it.

PHP 5.5 Preview: New Password Hashing API
Andy Podner gives us this well written intro to the new password hashing API coming to 5.5, how to use it, what it brings to the table, and the main benefits for using it.

Predicting Random Numbers In PHP – It’s Easier Than You Think!
An excellent write up by Pádraic Brady on why the use of mt_rand is not only never sufficient with cryptographic functions but indeed should be avoided for all but the most trivial operations, because it can actually be predicted due to the lack of entropy in the seeds used to generate random numbers, which entirely voids their usefulness.

A First Look at React
React is one of those extremely interesting new projects in PHP that opens up so many possibilities you probably didn't know could ever be possible. This article by Alexander Cogneau tells you all about the Node-esque async framework that React provides, how to get it, setting up an initial server/application, and where to go from there. As Igor Wiedler, creator of React, says himself it's probably not quite ready for production but if you're interested in one of the possible futures of non-blocking async in PHP then this might be for you, and Alexander does a good job summing it up.

The same app 4 times: PHP vs Python vs Ruby vs Clojure
Adam Bard wrote this post comparing a simple example application, which replaces non-nouns from a form post with the words "nurble", written in 4 different languages and platforms. I was of two minds whether to include this post as the PHP example is definitely not how the majority of PHP devs would write it and Adam even admits to having not even tested if it works because he didn't want to install Apache+PHP at the time. I decided to include it mostly for the other language examples (and links at the bottom of the article to examples in other languages/frameworks by third parties).

PHP is not dead
David Corbacho wrote this follow up to a 2007 article, PHP is dead... long live PHP! by Dries Buytaert which showed concerns about PHP 5 adoption at the time. In his article David shows that since then PHP 5 adoption as surpassed PHP 4 by orders of magnitude, backing up the claim with statistics and graphs from various dependable sources, interestingly including StackOverflow questions as a metric which I'd not thought of before (showing the rate of developer adoption by how many questions are being asked about that stack).

NetTuts+ Round Table #1: Should Exceptions Ever be Used for Flow Control?
This is a first in a series of roundtable discussions by NetTuts+, edited by Jeffrey Way, with regular contributors Csaba Patkós, Pavan Podila, Gabriel Manricks, Jonathan Cutrell, Aaron Kuzemchak, Ben Corlett all discussing the use, and abuse, of exceptions in flow control. Some great back and forth here in a subject that has many pros and cons, which rarely fails to polarise developer opinion. Personally I fall on the "it makes sense in some situations but it depends on your abstractions" camp, read along and see where you fall (and a try-catch pun in there somewhere but I'm tired so I'll skip it this time).

On empty return values
Larry Garfield expands on his brief tweet "Protip: If your function returns an array, and its no-data return is FALSE rather than an empty array, YOU'RE DOING IT WRONG!", by explaining what he means by "returns an array", in most cases this refers to the fact your function should return a collection (e.g. an iterable) as it's valid value, so empty values should be empty collections, and error cases should be exceptions. +1 on much of this, although I'd like to point out that the description of a function that returns a single item seems to get lost about half way through. Personally I'd say if your function returns a single item (even if that item is an array or iterable object) then a null or false value is perfectly acceptable, an an array() would indicate an actual value returned.

Projects

array_column
As I mentioned last week array_column is coming to PHP 5.5 but if you'd like to use it  in <5.5 projects then array_column author Ben Ramsey also published this user-space implementation, and even if the inbuilt array_column is available (e.g. you run this under 5.5) everything will continue to work as usual.

Wisdom
A domain name availability checking API, which uses the Whois component from React under the hood, allows you to see if a domain name has been registered or not, and has a very nice workflow for adding new TLDs.

JSONCharInputReader
An API for processing JSON data as a stream with event triggers, which means it's much more efficient for handling very large JSON datasets, and you can even get away with only processing the part of a stream you actually need (e.g. you've got 20mb of JSON but you only care about a couple of fields in the first 1mb, imagine doing this over 1000s of datasets and you begin to see the advantages).

AzaPhpGen
An extremely interesting library that could be described as a serialiser, but is actually a code generator. It takes PHP variables, objects, classes, functions (as closures) etc. and attempts to dump the underlying PHP code to a string. It is already very feature complete and has lots of potential use in caching, as well as template based code generation.

Laravel 4 Map
This handy utility for Laravel 4 reveals the underlying internal static interfaces, and those in dependencies such as Symfony2, that the higher level API wraps in facades (object instances, using DI).

item.title: Issue #14 for Saturday the 23rd of March 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #14 for Saturday the 23rd of March 2013

Sticking point

There was an impressive response to the free stickers offer last week, I've just received them from the excellent Diginate, and while not perfect (they're a little on the small side and the design needs some work) they're good for a first run, and I'll get them sent out next week to everyone who asked (and I'll stick some extra stickers in too for good measure as I seem to collect them).

On a more self-promotional note if you'd like to see/hear me give a talk on building and deploying large service orientated apps at the Berlin DevOpsDays then please give my proposal some likes or comments. :)

News & announcements

PHP 5.5.0 beta 1 available
It's finally here, opcode cache and all, first 5.5 beta for your QA purposes. This one is important to get testing folks as it's now a clear road to release. See the NEWS file for a list of additions, or read through the first 3 articles in the articles section below for various write ups.

PHP 5.4.13 and PHP 5.3.23 released
A few important bug fixes, include security issues, so get those package managers warmed up. See the ChangeLog for more details.

Laravel 4 beta 3 released
Laravel 4 is shaping up to be an awesome release, and this beta adds a raft of new features and fixes, with excellent code coverage in the tests to boot.

LoneStarPHP 2013 schedule released

Symfony Live Paris 2013 programme released

 

Audiovisuals

Laracon: Eloquence Emerging (video)
A break down by Taylor Otwell on the primary goals and idioms behind Laravel which is rather eloquent itself.

Laracon: Better Testing In Laravel 4 (video)
An excellent guide by Jeffrey Way on improving test usage and coverage in Laravel 4 applications, with great general advice for testing thrown in for good measure.

Laracon: Per Your Request (video)
Kenny Meyers takes us through what happens during a full request cycle, and how the request/response is handled by Laravel, from library calls to patterns and execution.

DC4D: Baby Steps to Ballroom Dancing: Getting on the Path to Speaking Success
Day Camp 4 Developers #5 looked amazing this year, with some amazing talks, not least of which was this guide by Elizabeth Naramore on overcoming "glossophobia" by making sure you don't throw yourself into the deep end, starting with topics you know well and audiences you can relate to easily. Good stuff.
 
DC4D: How to propose a talk and get it accepted
Laura Thompson gives us the low down on creating a great talk proposal, getting your initial ideas across to organisers and avoiding common mistakes.

DC4D: Preparing to Speak
A thorough walk through by Lorna Mitchell from 3 months prior to giving your talk, turning your abstract into that perfect presentation, making sure all your support material is covered, and knowing when you change things.
 

Articles

Introducing Array_column() in PHP 5.5
Ben Ramsey shows off his addition to PHP 5.5, the array_colum() function, which others may know as a pluck function, allowing you to easily select subvalues from an array structure, regardless of dimensions, with control over returned indices. An excellent addition to the language, and good introduction from it's author.

List of new features in PHP 5.5
A comprehensive list of new feature additions to PHP 5.5 by Nikita Popov, author of several of them, complete with links to RFCs and the author's name.

Using PHP 5.5's New "OPcache" Opcode Cache
A write up by Christopher Jones on building 5.5 with the new opcode cache and setting it up, along with the caveat that the new OPcache extension doesn't include a user data cache like APC does, and links to projects that add one as a separate extension.

Symfony Docs Hack Day Needs You on March 30th
Want to contribute to Symfony2 in one of the best ways possible? Several of the core team members will be holding a hack day on IRC (#symfony-docs on Freenode to be precise) on March 30th, 9am CET to 5pm EST, to strive to improve the documentation. Just hop on IRC, discuss things with people on there and get submitting pull requests for issues on GitHub. It's a great way to give back to the community and get your name added to improvements in a major open source project.

PHP version 5.3 is now the most used version, just ahead of 5.2
W3Techs, who collection tech stack statistics from various companies and individuals via surveys, reckon despite the fact 5.3 is at end-of-life this month, it has only just overtaken 5.2 adoption by about 3%. To be honest, I can believe it, we all know adoption is slow on any language/platform, especially one so closely tied to host providers who often just stick to current major releases, and continue to get patches from vendors such as RedHat for years after end of life. A commentor also points to Wordpress's stats which still show 5.2 ahead at over 60% for Wordpress installs.

PHPNE 2013 Conference Report
PHPNE 2013, the first large PHP conference held in the North East of England, looked like an amazing day and I'm sad I missed it, but I've been hearing great things. Adam Smith has written this excellent report on all the talks and other events during the day, which makes me look forward to attending next years (here's hoping).

26 Ways to Show that PHP Can Be Better Than PHP
Manuel Lemos of PHPClasses fame goes through a very extensive list of "missing" PHP features that can be provided by, or closely emulated, using userspace PHP code, and for each gives an example of an existing implementation. Some very clever libraries and workarounds listed here, although I must say one of my biggest bugbears is that most of these aren't in any form of public source control (e.g. GitHub, BitBucket etc.), making open source collaboration much more difficult.

Look mama, no databases
Michelangelo van Dam wrote this nice article on decoupling your code and your unit tests in turn from your database operations, by extracting out those operations to replaceable methods which can be overridden when mocking, meaning you can run your unit tests independent from a database instance or requiring any connections to one. A solid write up on a good principle for application design not just testing.

7php Interview With Stefan Priebsch A Co-Founder Of The PHP Consulting Company aka thePHP.cc
The prolific Khayrattee Wasseem brings us another 7php interview with a PHP community luminary, this time Stefan Priebsch, author, speaker and co-founder of thePHP.cc. The usual array of personal tips and recommendations from books to software and conference lay herein, personally I usually like to compare notes with other developers especially the parts that show they're just human (I have no time left these days ever Stefan!)

Using Stackato for PHP Applications in a Private PaaS
Andy Podner takes us through setting up and initial use of ActiveState's Stackato, which bills itself as a "free micro cloud", in other words an integrated suite of management applications and platform software (e.g. a mini lamp stack with apps for automatically managing and deploying applications via the stack, like a mini Heroku, AppFrog etc.) An intriguing idea in itself, Andy goes step by step through initial setup and an initial app, and covers ideas on how you might use it in your own setup.

First Serious Attempts with PHPUnit, Composer, and the Omniture API
Justin Carmony takes us through lessons he learnt using test driven development to to write a wrapper for Omniture's RESTful API, which after a weekend of hacking he has it almost complete and up on Packagist. Some good lessons for everyone here.

Some thoughts on using array_* with closures
Ashish Dattacovers one of my favourite subjects, using anonymous functions with the extensive set of array_* array manipulation functions built into PHP, which often produces clearer, cleaner and more precise code, and also allows more slightly more dynamic control over manipulation. One thing to note however is that if you're calling manipulation functions many times and over lots of arrays you'll usually get more performance out of a statically defined callback as opposed to a runtime defined closure.

Orno series part 1: Building a RESTful API
Phil Bennett takes us through developing a RESTful webservice with the Orno\Di dependency injection library and loosely coupled MVC component, which despite having covered before on PHP Weekly I was not aware just quite how awesome it is, allowing you do buildup application patterns using data structures (the good old trusty array) and leverage dependency injection to componentise each part of the app. Really excellent stuff, and one I'll be playing with in the future.

The dire state of WordPress
James Shakespeare probably isn't going to cause many gasps of surprise with this post, but he does succinctly describe a lot of problems with using, deploying, developing for and developing on Wordpress as it stands today. I've developed some heavy content managed sites on top of WP, a platform definitely not designed or suited for it but we still manage to wedge into and on top of, and James makes some good points about how WP is still one of the best options, even if it does have lots of disadvantages, and let's not ignore the install base alone means we need to seriously think about improvements, not just migration. I will add one point, if you're following this weekly and your primary exposure to PHP is via Wordpress, you're going to want to go to look at other resources right now. Please. :)

PHP courses on Codeacademy need you
Codeacademy recently added much awaited PHP courses to their list of guides, but the PHP ones are still incomplete and they'd like the community to help fill them in.

Projects

Bernard
A very nicely implemented message queue written in PHP and driven by Predis/Redis for push based message transports. Also includes based task running functionality backed by message queues.

Rhubarb
An incomplete but extremely well designed PHP client library for the Celery distributed task framework, which itself is primarily Python based. Although the non-AMQP backend support is lacking (interfaces are there but not yet implemented by the looks), this project already provides a very feature rich API.

PHP-CSS-Parser
A fairly complete CSS3 parser, with manipulation functionality.

 

PHP HTML5Lib
A full PHP implementation of a HTML5 tokenizer matching the WHAT-WG specifications. Put this together with the CSS parser above and you have pretty extensive web scraping/filtering toolset.

pulsar
A fork of the Symfony class [auto]loader but with PHP 5.1.3+ compatibility. Has several advantages of many class loaders, for example APC or XCache class map caching if available.

Phar Update
A lovely API for creating self-updating Phar archives, e.g. an archive which automatically updates itself from a URL whenever a certain new version spec if available.

APCu
A project to separate out APC's user cache into an extension on it's own, as the new opcache in 5.5 doesn't include a user cache.

Yac - Yet Another Cache
Another shared user cache project to run alongside other opcode caches, but this one is lockless by design.

item.title: Issue #13 for Saturday the 16th of March 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #13 for Saturday the 16th of March 2013

Back from hiatus

Sorry for the 2 week long gap between mailouts folks, last week was particularly taxing due to being away for work for half the week and coming home to a very sick wife. Thanks to everyone on Twitter who helped spread the word that there'd be no issue last week.

As I mentioned last issue I have an order in for some PHP Weekly stickers, everyone who entered the contest will get one, but I have 50 stickers to give out (keeping some back to keep in my bag), so if you'd like a free sticker email me your address. :-)

P.S. We'll be back to the regular Thursday schedule next week, promise.

News & announcements

PHP 5.5.0 alpha 6 released
A mostly bug fix release prior to the Zend Optimizer+ merge and the now longer road to 5.5 going gold. See the NEWS file for more details.

Community voted to delay 5.5 to integrate Zend Optimizer+
Great news for speeding up PHP out of the box (eventually), despite issues with it delaying the release schedule...and guess what? It's now been merged to master. To test the ZO+ opcache with PHP 5.2+ you can use the PECL extension today.

More PHP extensions available on Travis CI
The awesome continuous integration system that more and more open source projects are using to keep their code clean and their tests green (and fair few closed), now has more PHP extensions out of the box, and an easier process for enabling them in the php.ini used by the Travis worker VMs.

Zend Framework 2.1.4, 2.0.8, and 1.12.3 released
These new ZF2 and ZF1 releases fix a bunch of security problems, as well as various API fixes.

The Grumpy Programmer's PHPUnit Cookbook by Chris Hartjes released
Chris Hartjes, aka @grmpyprogrammer, has released a brilliant new ebook all about the sticky subject of unit testing and using good ol' PHPUnit to get the heavy work done. Highly recommended.

PHP-FIG vote to concentrate more on "hard" specs
Expect more so-called "hard" specs, e.g. defining actual interfaces for use in code like the recent Logging interfaces, and less coding standards suggestions.

 

First speakers announced for Symfony Live Portland 2013

Keynote speakers announced for php|tek13

Audiovisuals

Symfony Live videos
Some great videos of past Symfony Live talks have posted to the Symfony YouTube channel, most recently last years Berlin conference.

PHP Townhall Episode 5
PHP Townhall regular hosts Phil Sturgeon and Ben Edmunds are joined by Miko Federmann, and /dev/hell regular hosts Chris Hartjes and Ed Finkler. They covered the sticky subjects of the PHPness gate, industry sexism, and Chris's struggles with and tips for dealing with his depression and anxiety, which really struck a personal chord with me.

Lately in PHP Episode 33
Regular hosts Manuel Lemos and Ernani Joppert interviewed The PHP Programming Innovation Award Winner of 2012 Karl Holz , and went on to talk about various topics such as the Optimizer+ merge and Manuel's recent blog post comparing PHP to Hobbits.

/dev/hell Episode 29
Regular hosts Chris Hartjes and Ed Finkler went in their own words "RIchard Prior style" this episode just answering lots of questions from IRC, meaning they covered a plethora of topics from editors of choice to the latest blog posts.

Articles

PCI Compliance and the PHP Developer
As much as I dislike the "PCI standards" for various reasons, if you're dealing with customer credit card data you need to be aware of them, and this article by  David Shirey does an excellent job of simply explaining the ins and outs of achieving compliance from the standpoint of a PHP developer.

Extending an Iterator to use an Iterator to make your code a little cleaner
Bob Majdak Jr wrote this nice little example of extending Iterators objects in order to wrap the common new ThingIterator(new OtherThingIterator)) pattern you've probably used lots of times in your own code, making it much cleaner and simpler by doing the extra iterator instantiation in the extended class. Good stuff.

Integrate PHP application with Solr search engine
Lukasz Kujawa has written this concise step by step guide to getting Apache Solr up and running and how to use the Solr extension to perform search functions from your PHP application. Solr is a very nice search engine backend and if you need more than a *SQL full text search, like many serious apps do, this is a good route to take.

Scaling Silex applications (part II). Using RouteCollection
Following up his previous post on scaling Silex, Gonzalo Ayuso this time covering the use of the RouteCollection to wrap the underlying Symfony2 routing, not only making your code a bit cleaner but also making it easier to extend your routing without degrading maintainability.

Your One-Stop Guide to Laravel Commands
A fairly exhaustive guide by Jason Lewis to building command interfaces in Laravel 3 with Artisan, including accepting commands, arguments, options and asking for user input.

Building ePub with PHP and Markdown
A very interesting article by Vito Tardia  on generating ePub documents (most commonly used for eBooks) from markdown documents using PHP, various libraries and some very clever tricks and workarounds.

Composer: an update on require-dev
Jordi Boggiano of Composer fame informs us about an update to how Composer handles the "require-dev" field in packages, in that the entire feature has been rewritten by him, should be faster, and much more reliable. We actually noticed this at Server Density in our application builds before I saw Jordi's blog post, and has made our builds a lot simpler between different environments.

Valitron: The Simple Validation Library That Doesn't Suck
Vance Lucas announces his new validation library Valitron and explains his motivations for creating yet another validation library and why you should use it too. Interesting project and definitely one to use if like Vance you're building an app that doesn't already have the same dependencies a lot of other libraries have, or their interfaces frustrate you.

The Wheel: Symfony Console
Seems everyone's coving command libraries this week. In his new feature The Wheel, Giorgio Sironi wrote up the pros, cons, and general usage of the Symfony Console library.

Practical Aspects of the Adapter Pattern
Rakhitha Nimesh succinctly covers the practical uses of the Adapter pattern, with an analogy centring around controlling APIs via text messages, and a more real world PHP example for sending emails and tweets via a compatible interface.

How to Tell if Your PHP Site has been Hacked or Compromised
Steps to Take When you Know your PHP Site has been Hacked
In these two articles by Greg Freeman he goes step by step through various warning signs for a compromised PHP site, and how to respond to the situation. To these tips I would also add to make sure to keep up with application updates if running with an "off the shelf" solution like Wordpress/Drupal etc., and to regularly check updates to your dependencies if it's a bespoke application. If you're using Composer the security checker by SensioLabs is great for this.

Overloading: Create PHP Class Methods on the Fly
Although not strictly "overloading" in the true OO sense of the word, this article by Andy Podner on creating methods and static methods on-the-fly using a registry of anonymous functions with the correct arguments passed from call-time magic methods is a great little primer on a technique that can often make your code simpler and easier to extend.

PHP is the right tool for the job (for all the wrong reasons)
A pragmatic look by Samuel Levy on many of PHP "strengths", which detractors usually either forget about or conveniently concrete over in their arguments.

Unauthorized Access: Bypassing PHP strcmp()
A write up by Daniel Regalado on his attempt to work through the Codegate 2013 security challenge, in which he came across a common vulnerability caused using the strcmp() function to compare strings without checking the type of the value returned, similar to issue with strpos that almost everyone comes across. I commented on the blog why this happens, but I'd just like to add that for the purposes of checking hashes as in the challenge you should just use an equality operator directly rather than something that uses lengths in it's comparison, like strcmp.

Projects

caq
A possibly useful bash script that generates base applications for various frameworks from template files, seems to be easily extendable by defining your own templates and may be just what you need if you're always bootstrapping apps with common base files.

php-o
An API which wraps common scalar values and objects in PHP providing a "saner API", for example: echo s("abc")->len();

e2ex
A package that captures and convert PHP errors/warnings and converts them into actual exceptions, with optional logging via the excellent monolog library.

PHP Cron Expression Parser
A library for generating run-times based on datetime and repeatable configurations, e.g. like the cron unix daemon, with an inbuilt crontab syntax parser.

Box
A library for simplifying the creation or Phar archives, with a very nice API, could be just what you need for generating those phar's in your build steps.

Brainfart
A brilliantly implemented Brainfuck interpreter, self described by the author as being over engineered as he used it as an example for teaching a friend some of the more advanced features in 5.4. Even includes a complete unit test suite. *claps*

Inflector
A port of a popular Ruby library that allows you to perform inflections on English words, mostly with regards to code symbols, e.g. turn CamelCase to snake_case, or turn singular words to plural (great for data models), etc.

XHP
An interesting PHP extension by Facebook which adds XML elements as an actual first class type in PHP. Hard to explain so I'll give an example:
Instead of writing echo '<a href="' . $link . '">' . $title . '</a>';
You might use: echo <a href="{$link}">{$title}</a>;
Instead, and because these are actual PHP expressions inside real XML elements, you can do a lot more complex things beyond string interpolation.

Namespacer
A nice little library for wrapping old underscore separate libraries and accessing them via real namespaces.

 

Tweet of the week

Ruby:
Dir.mktempdir
Dir.tmpdir
Tempfile.open

Please, don't laugh at PHP inconsistency :-)
#php #ruby

— Ivan Enderlin (@hoaproject) March 7, 2013

item.title: Issue #12 for Saturday the 2nd of March 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #12 for Saturday the 2nd of March 2013

Something your somethingness

Bit of a slower week articles/news wise, in part probably due to last weekends unescapable controversy (unescapable in the way that it's everywhere you look).

I'm not going to talk much about this topic myself as I think the dead horse has probably been beaten enough, poor thing, but if you missed it check the last link below in the articles section for a good summary.

As I said last week I'll be having some PHP Weekly stickers made up as soon as I've finished up the design and checked it looks good when printed, originally planning to give these out to people who entered the giveaway but due to minimum order quantities it looks like I'll have a fair few left over, so what's a curator to do?

Give them away of course. If you'd like a sticker then watch this space (or Twitter etc.) for news and I'll be sending them out on a first come, first served basis.

Speaking of the Twitters, like seemingly the entire internet, I've recently gotten myself an App.net account, so if that's your preferred social media whatchamacallit service, you can find me there under usual monitor (1stvamp).

P.S. Sorry the issue is extremely late this week folks, life got in the way again.

10% off Mastering Object Oriented PHP by Brandon Savage

Awesome blogger, speaker, writer and Mozilla Socorro dev Brandon Savage has kindly offered readers of PHP Weekly 10% off the price of his new book Mastering Object Oriented PHP, which itself includes $100 off his Becoming An Object Oriented Master class.
Just use this discount code to get 10% off at checkout.

News & announcements

PHP 5.5.0 Alpha5 released
Missed this last week, latest 5.5 alpha, mostly as bugfix with minor features added, expect more fixes and less features as we approach release (maybe). See the NEWS file for details.

PHP 5.4.12 and PHP 5.3.22 released
10 bug fixes for the 5.4 and 5.3 branches, not greatly exciting but that's usually a good reason to upgrade early. See the ChangeLog for details.

Symfony 2.1.8 released
Lots of fixes, including some for nasty security issues, if Symfony2 is part of your stack and so often is even if you're not using it directly then look at updating now, the CHANGELOG has specifics.

Symfony 2.2.0 RC3 released
Probably the last release candidate before 2.2 goes gold next week, lots of fixes and tweaks, again if Symfony is part of your stack then you may want to start testing 2.2 now.

Zend Framework 1.12.2 released
ZF is still one of the most used frameworks out there, especially in enterprise environments, and this release has a massive 50 bugfixes and enhancements, especially if you use Zend_Service_Twitter to intereact with the Twitter API, which has been updated to support the recent Twitter API changes so it will continue to work after March.

 

Audiovisuals

Introduction to PHP 5.4.12 by Ilia Alshanetsky (from ConFoo 2013) slides
Bottleneck Analysis by Ilia Alshanetsky (from ConFoo 2013) slides
Ilia Alshanetsky gave these 2 fantastic talks at this years ConFoo and kindly shared the slides on his blog. The Bottleneck Analysis talk is of interest to everyone.

Articles

On predictable PHP release cycles
Lukas Kahwe Smith wrote this well reasoned argument against delaying the 5.5 release for 2 months to include the newly open sourced Zend Optimizer+ (which passed voting for inclusion), as he points out while PHP hasn't had a very predictable release cycle in the past, having one is an advantage to the community and this delay just makes things worse. While I agree for the most part I've seen a lot cross-community and cross-library issues with stringent release cycles like the one Canonical has with Ubuntu, and it can be hard to strike a balance between predictable and shackled.

On PHP-FIG
The prolific Matthew Weier O'Phinney shared his thoughts and feelings on the PHP-FIG's effectiveness and weaknesses, and his choice to step down from the organisation he founded. While he sets out a substantial list of issues with current FIG practices, and hurdles yet to overcome, his main reason appears to be that he's tired of dealing with it all and feels he has things he'd rather be getting on with in his life. Power to you Matthew.

Rock On, Refactor, or Re-roll?
Andy Podner wrote up his recent experience at work, tackling an issue many of us developers face: live with it, refactor or restart from scratch, and the struggle of choosing the pragmatic approach or the "fun" path. He finishes up with a very balanced solution, something relevant for everyone.

C-based Web Frameworks for PHP
Fortrabbit co-founder Ulrich Kautz goes into the pros and cons of C based PHP frameworks, how they provide massive amounts of speed and memory advantages, but can be a pain to debug if you're not familiar with C. Good write up and some excellent points, and one that I feel definitely backs up the notion that these framework driven functions are in such high demand by real developers that perhaps more should be provided by the engine itself.

Next big thing in PHP
Florin Razvan Patan not only gets his crystal ball out and tries to predict the next big feature set or shift in attitudes, but he also covers similar gripes a lot of people are expressing at the moment, most famously Phil Sturgeon, in that real developers are asking for features to be included in core that would make their lives easier and many feel those concerns are being ignored because of a vocal few. As well as this Florin reckons PHP is on a slow death march, with less contribution, performance problems, etc., and that there should be a big community push to make PHP6 a break from the past, with a cleaned up and more performant engine at it's core.

7php - A Comprehensive Interview With Zurmo CRM Tool
Another excellent interview from Khayrattee Wasseem, this time with Zurmo CRM co-founder Ray Stoeckicht. They talk about Ray's background, why he and Jason Green created Zurmo, what makes it different from other CRMs, and how they have impressively avoided the traditional "open core" approach that others like SugarCRM have embraced. Good stuff.

Functional Programming and PHP
A solid overview of functional programming basics by Shameer C, with lots of PHP examples, covering how you can achieve the fundamentals of functional programming such as immutability, recursion, referential integrity and pure vs impure functions, as well as discussing the pros and cons and why you might like to consider embracing functional programming for your next project. +1.

Use the Accept Header to Set Your Return Data With Zend Framework 2
Jason Fox details a nice little method in ZF2 for changing how return data is formatted or encoded (e.g. markup, XML, JSON etc.) based on the Accept HTTP header sent by the client, which works especially well with frontend JS apps, as well in public APIs and means you don't have to provide every URI mapping under the sun for each return format.

Taiming repository classes in Doctrine with the QueryBuilder
Anne from EasyBib describes an elegant solution for extending a Doctrine repository class with a generic get*/findAll//findBy*/filterBy*​ API that is maintainable and extensible without there being a mess of edge-case methods cluttering up the class. Very clever and well written, would be good to seea generalised class open sourced for this. 

Why objects (usually) use less memory than arrays in PHP
The brilliant Nikita Popov wrote this quick but detailed gist on the internals of object vs array memory usage in PHP core, how objects aren't always heavier than arrays due to how the hash table for an object is constructed for non-dynamic properties in >=5.4, how this means objects especially with large data structures will often be smaller overall (despite a large base footprint) than arrays and faster to access. There are some great takeaways from this at the end, read on for more.
 
The Definitive PHP Style Guide
A tongue-oh-so-firmly-embedded-in-cheek alternative to the PSRs, with such wonderful nuggets as:
  • All classes, functions and methods MUST have a line of ///// after the opening braces to delimit the beginning of them. You're probably best off using the full 857 character limit just incase someone views it on a hi-res screen.
  • Comments MUST be right-aligned, using tabs, to improve readability.
  • All variable, constant, class, method and function names should [be] EXACTLY 8 characters long.
Perhaps not one to try at home folks.

PHPDeveloper.org: Sexism & Community
Not going to say any more on this subject, but I will advise you read everything about it if you haven't followed it already, as even if you think some of it has been blown out of proportion as many do it has still had a large impact on the community this week.

Projects

AzaThread
A nicely done library for running code in "threads", well not actually threads, it emulates them by forking extra processes and using inter process messages to control, inject and return data. Very nice API, with an inline fallback for systems that don't support forking.

Go
Not to be confused with the Google programming language or the aspect orientated library, this is a simple build tool inspired functionally by Ruby's Rake.

Stash
A cache abstraction library, at it's core provides a dependency-injection-container-like API but with support for various caching backends to allow persisting a cached value across requests, currently supports: files, APC, Memcached, and sqlite, but it is easily extendible with new drivers and also allows using multiple staggered drivers.

MtHaml
HAML for PHP, inspired unsurprisingly by the Ruby library, with first-class Twig integration,

Purl
No, not the language with a camel on all the O'Reilly, this elegant library provides methods for parsing a URI into it's constituent parts and manipulating them.

PHPSandBox
A framework for running PHP code safely in a sandbox that works by parsing, validating and if need be cleaning the code, even swapping inbuilt/global functions in place with wrappers. Nicely done and if you're in the position of needing to execute code from a source that isn't your own this could be for you.

TOML libraries
After Tom Preston-Warner, of GitHub fame, released his TOML spec the other day there seems to have been an explosion of PHP TOML libraries, I'll leave it as an exercise for the reader for find the best one:
  • leonelquinteros/php-toml
  • jamesmoss/toml
  • coop182/toml-php
  • checkdomain/toml
  • zidizei/toml-php

PHP Weekly

Issue #11 for Friday the 22nd of February

"I wish everyone could be a winner, sir."

News & announcements

PHP 5.4.12 and PHP 5.3.22 released
Lots of nigly little bugs fixed, see the changelog for a complete listing. (Shameless self promotion, includes my fix for bug 62524.)

Zend Framework 2.1.2 released
60 patches for bug fixes and cleanup from 2.1.1 added in this release, plus full documentation for the Session component, bump those composer.json's.

Bolt 1.0 released

 

Audiovisuals

Design Patterns - Programming With Anthony
Anthony Ferrara back with another excellently executed technique-revealing video, this time joined by Larry Garfield of Drupal fame, all about design patterns and how embracing their use, or at the very least being aware of them, can increase your code maintainability and reuse. Everything is backed up by well thought out concrete examples, and cooking tips.

Beautiful Models in PHP
The slides from Brandon Savage's PHP UK 2012 talk on modelling data in PHP, well worth a glance over, if only to understand the difference between modelling data in your application and storage (e.g. database backends).

PHP Town Hall Episode 4: PHP's Vision, Beards, and Cake
Regular podcast hosts Phil Sturgeon and Ben Edmunds are joined this time by CakePHP core dev Jose Diaz-Gonzalez and bearded-Laravel-whisperer Zack Kitzmiller, to talk the talk mostly about the future direction of PHP, reactions to/opinions about Phil's slighty-incendiary blog post, and comparisons with other languages like Python and Ruby.

Articles

PHP OOP Test
Matthew McConnell started this interesting discussion on reddit about testing a candidates programming skills before an interview, and even shares the test he's trying. This is one of those necessary evils when interviewing that is difficult to find the right balance with, and there's plenty of good advice here.

A Journey on Avoiding Nulls in PHP
Michael Nitschinger is on a mission to never type if ($foo === null) { throw blah; } again, and he's reached a clever solution by borrowing the Option concept from Scala and Google Guava Java framework. A good write up of uses for the option/optional pattern and a simple port of the Google classes included.

Don't use PHP libraries with known security issues
Fabien Potencier announces SensioLabs new service, a PHP Security Advisories Checker for Composer projects. This is a brilliant idea, with website, RESTful web service, and command line tool, that works by checking the versions of dependencies in your composer.json against SenioLabs CVE repository, and allows you with both manual and automated ways of checking for insecure deps in your projects. Bonus tip in the comments from Jordi Boggiano of Composer fame on using hooks to automatically check for issues on composer.lock update.

Preventing CSRF Attacks
A typically great write up by Anthony Ferrara on CSRF attacks and their prevention in PHP apps, with each stage of prevention broken down with examples, and most importantly why you should do it this way.

Would this be a dumb idea for PHP core?
An interesting proposal (not a formal RFC, he's just putting it out there so to speak) by Kevin Schroeder to add some method to PHP to allow keeping a global application state cache between PHP invocations (between requests/PHP interpreter executions) in order to minimise application bootstrapping times, e.g. autoloading classes, core object instances, globals etc. Using something like APC, or the newly open sourced (and possibly coming to core) Zend Optimizer+, opcodes are cached between interpreter instances, however a lot CPU cycles/memory is burnt just loading initial app state and this could definitely be a big performance boost, but there are valid concerns.

7php Interview With PPI – The PHP Meta-Framework
Khayrattee Wasseem interviews Paul Dragoonis again, this time about the PPI Framework, from the why he started to the project, to what exactly a meta framework is anyway, and why you might just want to make PPI2 your next framework of choice. I love meta frameworks and PPI2 is pretty much the only major player as far as PHP meta frameworks go, and definitely one to watch/use.

Setting Up A Staging Environment
A detailed write up by Gabriel Manricks on creating a localised staging environment, using one of my favourite tools Vagrant, that emulates your PaaS of choice (in the case of the article Fortrabbit) and allows you to test your project in as close as possible an environment to your production deploy target. Some nice tips and tricks, especially creating git hooks in a local bare repo to mimic git push based deploy processes.

Wrapping a PHP class for easy method chaining
Stefano Azzolini gives us a simple method and wrapper class for enabling method chaining on existing instances, which if you're not familiar with the concept you've probably used it with jQuery chained methods.

Dependency Injection Container Question
Matt Frost has thrown out this tricky question about using DICs with dependencies that require extra dependencies via parameter injection, and whether there is place for both paradigms at the same time. Using both together doesn't sit well with Matt, and I can see why, personally I'd tackle this using containment wrappers to allow use of shared dependencies within the DIC that can be passed on instantiation to other dependencies from within the wrapper. The main problem then becomes not just reinventing a registry pattern. My 2 pence so to speak.

Testing Like a Boss in Laravel: Models
A detailed and thorough write up by Zizaco Zizuini on testing Laravel 4 models using some of the better third party packages to make your life that bit easier, one favourite tip of mine being the use of an in-memory database (using SQLite) to speed up test execution.

Closures, Lambdas, and Anonymous Functions
An excellent article by Andy Podner on lambdas, the distinction between lambdas and closures, and where you might use either in your code. Lambdas and closures are awesome and I honestly believe PHP devs need to use these common CS constructs more, especially given the new ability in 5.4 to use $this in closures, there are many more possibilities for making our instances more dynamic.

Looking back: Sunshine PHP 2013
Jacob Mather wrote up his experiences at last weeks Sunshine PHP, with some understandable name dropping, and tips on how to get the most out of a good PHP conference.

Projects

I Feel PreTTY
A lovely little library for formatting your output from command line apps to come out all pretty with colours and layouts in the terminal.

httpful
Yet another HTTP library but httpful has a brilliant chainable API that definitely makes web API calls mucher nicer. Here's an idea for free, libraries like Httpful and Guzzle should share a common HTTP lib, similar to how whole frameworks are beginning to share common decoupled components.

composerdoc
A helper package that adds a utility to your Composer package to auto-generate dependency documentation.

archer
A framework for standardising unit tests and continuous integration runs against a set of predefined conventions, that if you follow give you some great benefits, like using the best quality tools and automatic features.

EmailReplyParser
A PHP port of GitHub's excellent Ruby email parser. If you work with email responses from external sources such as users you should seriously consider this utility, it's based on one of the best parsers of it's kind and this seems to be a well done port.

RFCorner

A quick look at interesting RFCs in discussion or possibly even coming to a future PHP release.

Trailing comma function args
This extremely simple proposal by Sara Goleman (yes, that awesome Sara Goleman) to allow function calls to have a trailing comma similar to arrays, e.g. str_replace('test', 'blah', $foo,);
An excellent idea that adds more consistency to the language and has several of the same advantages as trailing commas in array definitions. Yes it adds backwards incompatibility but this is really just a problem for open source projects aiming for older versions in that they'd have to lint for trailing commas, but they have to do that anyway now!

array_column
This proposal by yet another well known PHPer, Ben Ramsey, is at the voting stage, and based on the votes (which seems to have ended last month?) will definitely now make it into a future release. This adds a new array_column function, that acts very much like the PDO fetchColumn method, and allows you to pluck a specific column of data from a multi-dimensional array, which is a fantastic idea that I'm sure will reduce a lot of peoples code.

item.title: Issue #10 for Friday the 15th of February 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #10 for Friday 15th February 2013

The giveaway that wouldn't die, part II - the revenge

Last week I attempted to give away 2 prizes (see last weeks intro for the skinny) to mark reaching over 500 subscribers, well that didn't go so well because I made a classic newbie mistake when it comes to giveaways: I forgot to check if the recipients actually wanted them.
One recipient won't answer my emails (and has apparently never opened an issue of the weekly anyway), and the other has graciously declined either prize as he wouldn't get much use out of them (sincere thanks James!)

So let's try this again, if you'd like one of the two prizes I mentioned, email me telling me which one you'd like or that you'd like both.
As simple as that, before next weeks issue I'll run this script over the emails for the people who have opted in and email the two winners back.

As it turns out I can now claim this is to celebrate reaching over 650 subscribers, which is nice. At this rate I'll be looking for some cool things to give away for the grand mark.

Finally tooting my own horn a little I've submitted a talk proposal for DevOpsDays London titled Island Life: How we built and deployed the Honshū way and if you fancy hearing me talk about large scale deployments and graceful inter-dependant HTTP services then maybe give it a like, if you want. :)

News & announcements

Zend released Zend Optimizer+ as open source
In order to further the ambitions of the much talked about proposal to integrate the Zend Optimizer+ opcode cache into PHP core itself, Zend have released it fully as open source on GitHub, under the PHP license natch. It's definitely looking good that this will make it in, although I've seen a lot of comments on reddit hoping for it to become a PECL package either way.

php|tek conference schedule posted
Just as in previous years php|tek is shaping up to be an awesome conference, and they've posted the schedule featuring some extremely well known and interesting speakers on the roster.

Lone Star PHP call for papers
Lone Star PHP is another great conference that will be happening in June in Dallas, and they've put out a CFP, if you think you might have some interesting and relevant to talk about, why not head over and submit a proposal?

Propel 1.6.8 released with tonnes of bugfixes

 

Audiovisuals

Arduino "Basic Blink" Using PHP
Admittedly not an awful lot happens in this video, and yet it's rather impressive at the same time. Thomas Weinert shows off the first demo of his Carica IO project which implements the Firmata microcontroller protocol in a non-blocking PHP library. What does it do? Right now it makes an LED on an Arduino blink, but the possibilities are great.

Austin PHP - REST Best Practices
A well presented talk by Twilio's Dr Keith Casey Jr covering the key elements of a RESTful web service, gotchas and best practices.

Articles

Composer Stability Flags
Igor Wiedler, of Composer, Symfony2 and Silex fame, put together a very succinct description of how minimum-stability and version/stability resolution in Composer works, as well as whitelisting on a per package basis different minimum stability using flags. This is one of those things, as Igor states, that comes up on IRC all the time (in fact I've answered it in #composer-dev a few times myself), and one to read up on if you're confused by why certain packages complain about different versions like this.

Debugging Silex applications just got fun
Fabien Potencier wrote a little about how both Symfony2 and Silex gain a lot from using the Symfony HttpKernel component, despite one being a full stack framework and the other being a microframework, but that you sometimes miss certain developer utilities and functions that ship with a full stack like Symfony2, but one such component the Symfony web profiler can be added via a Silex provider.

Logging with PSR-3 to Improve Reusability
A nice primer and tutorial by Patrick Mulvey on using the PSR-3 logger interfaces to improve component reusability in your code, as well as using the adaptor to allow incompatible loggers to still work with the PSR-3 interface, reducing the coupling of your code with a specific component, and the amount it needs to know about how that component works.

RESTful APIs with ZF2 part 1
RESTful APIs with ZF2 part 2
Matthew Weier O'Phinney is writing this series of how-to's based on a workshop he and Rob Allen gave at PHP Benelux 2013, all about the ins and outs of creating a RESTful API, with an introduction to the Richardson Maturity Model, hypermedia and the Hypertext Application Language, followed by real world cases and how to achieve them using Zend Framework 2. Good stuff.

The Mysterious PHP RFC Process and How You Can Change the Web
An excellent and fairly exhaustive list of dos and don'ts for creating your first RFC/proposal for extending PHP, with simple advice like mailing internals if you're new, including an implementation with your proposal for maximum effect and my particular favourite advice strive to do better than current RFCs.

Parsing XML With SimpleXML
SimpleXML is one of the truly wonderful builtin libraries in PHP which I miss whenever working with another platform. Sandeep Panda gives us this small walkthrough on how to use it to parse a simple DOM and get data out using the object property notation.

PHP5.5: Try/Catch/Finally
Joshua Thijssen goes into detail about what the new finally keyword does in PHP 5.5 and why you might need it, as well as what it's advantages are over how you may have performed cleanup from an exception before 5.5 (clue: finally will always execute before the try-catch block is left, meaning it will even run before an exception which isn't caught by the block). Good to see a greater level or detail and real examples being shown.

My Love / Hate Relationship With PHP Traits
A good write up of what traits in 5.4 really bring to the table, how they can be used in a sensible fashion to extend an object functionality without much fuss, and a few warnings about how they can be abused (although personally I'm not so fearful of them, but then I spend most of my time in completely dynamic runtimes were multiple inheritance and "sideways" object extension are normal).

Generating secure cross site request forgery tokens (csrf)
Kevin Schroeder put together this post on generated CSRF anti-forgery tokens and how many people are doing it wrong by rand() and uniqid() builtin functions as they don't use enough entropy when generating random output and so often produce predictable results, which you definitely don't want in an anti-forgery token. Kevin describes instead using the better openssl_random_pseudo_bytes() to generate tokens, and that you don't really need a hash of your token either.

Of Creating User Groups and Physics
Some typical well written thoughts by Rafael Dohms on creating and continuing to grow a user group, with an excellent analogy to thermodynamics.

Free Control Panel for Zend Optimizer Plus
This author decided to hack together a quick and dirty control panel script for the newly open sourced Zend Optimizer+, and also shared a couple of insights to the API and what it does/doesn't tell you about the internal cache.

Microframework using anonymous functions
Emanuele Minotto created this one-script microframework using mostly just anonymous functions as registered callbacks. Putting this here rather than in projects as the gist reads more like a how I did it guide with some nice details and tricks.

External processes and PHP
Giorgio Sironi goes over the various ways of invoking an external process from PHP and you can gain greater controls over processes and output using the Streams API.

Projects

GitList
An online Git repository viewer with a lovely design and some nice features.

PHPHint
Both a web service and open source project that provides a web based PHP linter to check your code quality and catch any nasty unnoticed issues.

stamp
Based on the Ruby library of the same name stamp allows you to parse and display datetimes without needing to remember a single arcane parameter or date() call. Very nice.

Gaufrette
Gaufrette is a filesystem abstraction library which means in simple terms that you can work with files and file structures using an abstracted API in your app and not actually care where those files are stored or how, so when you need to change to a different file store (e.g. switch from local to Amazon S3, or just to a different location locally etc.) you can quite easily. You can also add caching on time of slow stores, amongst other great features.

Faker
Anonymising live data for testing? Creating fake user data? Stress testing etc. etc. Well Faker might just be the lib for you, does what it says on the tin, generates sets of Fake data from given constraints, with some very nice preloaded types of fake data set.

mongounit
An extension for PHPUnit that adds some handy utilities for testing MongoDB stored data.

item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #8 for Friday the 8th of February 2013

if (count($subscribers) > 500) { giveaway(); }

I said last issue that I'd try to do something special to mark the occasion of hitting the 500+ subscriber mark (now at 530+ as of typing), and the brilliant Cal Evans, Pelé of the PHP Community and friend of PHP Weekly, and my employer and list sponsor Server Density, have come through with a couple of great prizes.

In the interests of fairness, and not wanting to do any scummy Please RT for a chance to win! crap, I decided to just write a quick PHP script to randomly 2 subscribers to each win a gift (after removing myself and anyone else connected to the prizes).

Onto the prizes!

Cal very kindly donated a ticket to Day Camp 4 Developers #5: Public Speaking for Developers, a fantastic looking online only conference all about giving talks to user groups, colleagues, tech conferences and more, with big names like Laura Thompson and Lorna Jane Mitchell offering up their expertise and experiences on public speaking (I'll definitely be there at my screen for it.)

Server Density have donated a years free starter package, offering monitoring for up to 100 servers and up to 100 websites, 1000 SMS credits, e-mail/phone support, and more.

I've run the script and emailed the winners that popped up, not got any reply back, but hopefully they'll accept and let me tell you who they are.

News & announcements

Zend Framework 2.1.1 released
40 patches with a whole tonne of fixes for 2.1 in this release, if you're using ZF 2.1 you won't want to miss this release.

Idiorm and Paris 1.3.0 released - the minimalist ORM and fluent query builder for PHP
Idiorm is a tiny yet flexible ORM and and Paris is an active record implementation built on top of Idiorm. For some time they didn't receive much love as their original author had moved on, but new maintainer Simon Holywell has pushed 1.3.0 out the doors, and things are looking up, with new features, bug fixes, and a solid plan for the future.

Web & PHP magazine issue 11 is out
Latest Web & PHP magazine, released as usual for free, has some good cloud based articles, and a preview of PHP UK, which is just 2 weeks away now.

 

Audiovisuals

PHP Quick Tip: When to use the alternative syntax
Ben Everard walks us through what context he chooses to use the "alternative syntax" for IFs in PHP, e.g. mostly when mixing PHP with markup in templates, as he feels it provides a syntax much closer to the element level markup in HTML.

FLOSS Weekly #239: Concrete CMS
A favourite podcast of mine, this episode has regular host Randall Schwartz and semi-regular co-host Simon Phipps interviewing Franz Maruna, one of the lead developers behind Concrete 5, which until now hadn't crossed my radar but it certainly seems like a good contender in the highly competitive CMS space.

Lately in PHP podcast episode 32
Regular hosts Manuel Lemos and Ernani Joppert discussed MySQL 5.6 performance improvements, MySQL being replaced by MariaDB in some popular distros, the news about Zend Optimizer+ possibly being merged into PHP, and more.

Articles

Netcraft: PHP just grows & grows
Andy Ide, from the internet host metrics company Netcraft, released their stats on PHP use in 2013, and then did some neat graphs and stats on PHP usage growth since the original "Personal HomePage Tools" in 1995. Spoiler: it's up to 244m unique hostnames running PHP in some form, with possibly a higher host installbase, not to mention the hosts that hide the fact they're running PHP or hosts not surveyed by Netcraft's bots. Wow.

How to Make Async Requests in PHP
Calvin French-Owen, segment.io co-founder, shares his experiences trying to achieve what he terms asynchronous, but really he means non-blocking, HTTP client requests from PHP, from using immediately closed socket connections (with various techniques, and caveats), to batching requests with a second process, and forking out cURL processes. Some good ideas and conclusions.

Doctrine and SOLID
If the SOLID pattern is your thing then Benjamin Eberlei  gets down to the nitty gritty of getting your Doctrine2 models to use "value objects" which extract business logic components into child entities of the model. Benjamin continues to explain that unfortunately Doctrine doesn't support embedded objects like this, and until he manages to get support for them into core, he provides a few alternatives.

Benchmarking Cache Transcoders in PHP
Michael Nitschinger runs through a few techniques for serialising PHP objects, with an eye for storing objects in a caching system such as memcached. Some interesting benchmarks, with the wildcard being transforming objects to scalar values such as an array and serialising to JSON. The igbinary extension comes out on top for smaller sizes when serialising small sets of complex objects, but if speed is your thing the inbuilt object serialisation in PHP comes out on top.

Managing PHP Application Builds with Phing
Andy Podner covers a subject close to my heart, application build systems, with an old favourite Phing (I once created a Composer-like sandboxed system for Phing, called baskit) which is ant-like build system for PHP powered by verbose yet readable XML files. Andy goes over the first steps installing and setting up Phing for your project, as well as some future possibilities for what you can use it for.

Simply scale with Nginx, Memcached, PHP-FPM and APC
Although we recently linked to an article explaning that in a basic 1-to-1 comparison, with certain filesystem IO heavy ops disabled, Apache can keep up with Nginx on concurrent connections to PHP apps, James Fuller covers the many-many reasons for still choosing Nginx + PHP-FPM to deploy and scale your app.

7php - Zend Certifications Tips & Tricks
Khayrattee Wasseem interviews Zend Certified PHP Engineer Michelangelo van Dam about the Zend Certification itself, covering what it is, what it isn't, tips, tricks and addressing some widely held criticisms. Some very good advice for anyone thinking of becoming a ZCE (really, consider it, I did many years ago and it was quite worth it), and it's part 1 in a series of articles, so expect more helpful advice from other ZCEs in action.

How to Write Code That Embraces Change
This well written piece by Patkos Csaba is a good introduction to many object orientation techniques and patterns for keeping your codebase responsive to design changes while remaining maintainable. Patkos goes over a whole gamut of principles, from object cohesion, to orthogonality, dependency, coupling and even SOLID.

How to configure Symfony’s Service Container to use Twitter API
Gonzalo Ayuso shows us how to use Symfony2's wonderful service container system to wrap Twitter's REST API with just some simple YAML configuration, producing an elegant object mapping for the API.

Parallel PHPUnit
PHPUnit is great for running simple unit tests, and even integration tests, but as it runs sequentially in a single PHP process it doesn't exactly make use of all the available resources on most machines/VMs. Giorgio Sironi shares his experience trying out Paratest to run PHPUnit tests as multiple processes in parallel, producing aggregated results by parsing JUnit compatible XML output from the tests. Some good results, with a 25% saving in Giorgio's basic tests, but read carefully for caveats, and stay tuned for more results from his experiments.

Laravel 4: A Start at a RESTful API
Chris Fidao goes into a fair bit of detail on creating a simple RESTful HTTP API with L4, from initial project setup to routing, models and resourceful controllers.

Projects

ownCloud
Ever wanted your own Dropbox? ownCloud is an open source "cloud" (and by cloud we mean web service, effectively) storage, file syncing and media sharing platform, written in PHP (although other components, such as the syncing client, use different platforms).

MediaWiki Diff
Diff works either as an extension to MediaWiki (the software that powers Wikipedia) or as a standalone tool and provides utilities for generating diffs between JSON or JSON like data structures.

Temp-Token
A nice library for generating unique one-time time-limited tokens, especially good for password reset forms.

Flow
A fork of the original Twig templating system by Armin Ronacher, which you may know from the later fork that is part of Symfony. Flow extends the original concept of Twig with lots of extra features, influenced by Armin's later Python templating library Jinja2, the Symfony version of Twig and the Django templating system.

dnode-php
A PHP implementation of the DNode RPC protocol which allows you to write agents in PHP which can run and process jobs in a DNode cluster alongside Node.js agents, very cool.

woodhouse
A clever library for publishing build artefacts and status images to a GitHub repo from within a build process, e.g. updating build information in a README at the end of a build/test run on TravisCI for example.

 

RFCorner

Integrating Zend Optimizer+ into the PHP distribution
One of the biggest pieces of news this past week were these efforts to either release the Zend Optimizer+ system as the default opcode cache in PHP 5.5, or at the very least release it as an open source PECL extension if that falls through. Given the many advantages of O+ over the current "default" choice for opcode caches, APC, this is great news and I hope it becomes part of the default distro.
I was curious as to what Rasmus thought of it given that he is lead maintainer of APC, and his reply was promising.
PHP Magazin also have a good write up of the discussion, and the current main roadblock to the integration.
