item.title: Issue #8 for Thursday the 31st of January 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #8 for Thursday the 31st of January 2013

Be a lover, not a hater

This weeks issue marks PHP Weekly passing the 500 subscribers mark, so I think that deserves something special, however I didn't manage to come up with anything so I'll have to think of something for next week (a competition? Random giveaway? Send me ideas!)

Special thanks to Paul Dragoonis, Max Schwanekamp and Kim Rowan who all gave me help with content for this issue, and kind words of support for the mailout. Cheers!

News & announcements

Zend Framework 2.0.7 and 2.1.0 released
2.0.7 is the last 2.0 release with over 150 bugfixes, while 2.1.0 is the brand spanking new ZF2 feature branch with all new components, such as Zend\Test for your unit and integration testing needs.

 

Audiovisuals

Ilia Alshanetsky's PHP Benelux talks (slides)
Ilia gave some fascinating talks at PHP Benelux on Application Logic Security and PHP 5.4, and he has graciously shared them as PDFs.

ProTalk - online audio & video community resource
A great resource site collecting recordings of talks and tutorials from around the net with mostly PHP related content on there right now.

Articles

Comfortable PHP Editing With VIM
Tobias Schlitt has a very thorough PHP dev environment setup in my own favourite editor-come-IDE vim, which he has shared on GitHub, and also blogged about various snippets he uses. Great stuff.

1.5x … 9x faster queries with PHP and MySQL 5.6, really?
Ulf Wendel dives into the soon to be released MySQL 5.6's Memcache protocol support which effectively runs a version of memcached with MySQL and allows you to perform basic key-value queries with the binary TCP/IP or socket memcache protocol. It turns out doing this is quite fast, with as much as up to 9x speedups on certain queries. As Ulf says this works well in projects where you're basically doing simple key-value queries, and adding a caching layer like this can even speed some more complex queries, but use with caution. Remember there is no silver bullet for databases.

Intro to PHP Comments and Docblocks
Andrew Podner covers the often grey world of commenting your code, with some black and white details on the phpDocumentor sorta-standard for docblocks, how you can use it document classes/methods/functions etc., and some simple advice on general commenting.

PHP 6: Pissing in the Wind
You gotta love Phil Sturgeon's penchant for not mincing his words, this time on the subject on progressing PHP with new language features and cleaning up old language warts. From recent bitchfests in the community, stubborn, blind and quite rude attitudes and responses to perfectly valid requests from real developers are sadly becoming the norm. Phil puts forward some great suggestions for how we can improve this and move forward with the language as a community, but as the comments suggest it's not going to be easy. (Possibly some NSFW language.)

7php Interview With Paul Dragoonis CTO At BestBuys.com
Khayrattee Wasseem is back with another awesome interview with a PHP community luminary, this time friend-of-PHPWeekly and fellow Brit Paul Dragoonis, who shares the highs and lows of organising a tech conference, how he runs BestBuys.com, his love for the PHP community, tips about being a better developer, and much more. As usual check it out.

Composer: Speeding up class autoloading
Patrick Allaert proposes a very elegant solution to speeding up class autoloading in Composer beyond the option --optimize-autoloader by creating PSR-0 (for those packages which use PSR-0 for a namespace mapped file structure) mapping symlinks to class files so that the autoloader just has to point directly at were it thinks the corresponding file should be on the filesystem. He asks the Composer project leaders if this could be baked in as an extra option, but checkout the comments for more thoughts and possible issues.

GeoLocation with FourSquare and Google Maps tutorial
Paul Dragoonis over on the PPI Blog has this well put together tutorial on geolocation using FourSquare, Google Maps and of course the PPI framework, with an example project repo on GitHub, and lots of snippets for generating maps and doing other geo ops.

Dependency Injection with Pimple
A clear concise tutorial by Rakhitha Nimesh on using the Pimple dependency injection container to start using the DI pattern in your apps, encapsulating logical components in a reusable way and getting rid of those nasty global configuration painpoints.

Setting up a PHP development environment on a VPS
Aaron Pollock takes us through the process of creating your very own dev environment on a VPS for various well explained reasons, e.g. always having access to your environment, not caring about opening ports on your machine, having a single IP to test public APIs (especially useful for webhooks and OAuth return addresses) etc. Although some of these can be quite easily mitigated with a local VM solution like Vagrant, Aaron makes some good points and if a VPS env is the way for you he provides a solid guide.

When To Write Bad Code
With all the recent code hate on the web Brandon Savage reminds us that not even can start their project from a point of perfection, be they inexperienced, in a rush or just don't need to, not all code is or should be perfect, but he goes on to explain how that "bad code" that actually got written can be refactored, and when either point makes sense.

Projects

dependency.me
A website and open source project that analyses the dependencies in your Composer package and tells you if any of them stale and out date, including provides a cool little TravisCI-like status badge that you can include in you README.

scalar_objects
This is an extension by the prolific Nikita Popov that allows you to register handlers for scalar types (strings, numbers, arrays etc.) so that you can then perform operations on them using method calls, e.g. $string->length() rather than strlen($string). Very very cool.

EasyRdf
A library with a simple OO API for generating and manipulating RDF documents.

 

handy
A data model API for migrating data between different models, such MySQL tables.

A standalone or Laravel4 deployment app with simple configuration, worth a look if you don't fancy setting up something more complicated like Puppet, Chef, Salt etc.

item.title: Issue #7 for Friday the 25th of January 2013
item.description:
Fresh(ish) PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #7 for Friday 25th of January 2013

Better late than never, amirite?

A bit of a bumper issue this week, on account of my being a very naughty boy (and definitely not the messiah) last week and missing the issue completely due to various reasons (chief amongst them being my wedding anniversary, note to self: next year just tell everyone you're not doing the issue outright).

I've also managed to slip sending this out by a day, going out on Friday rather than Thursday, the main reason for this is that the problem with having 2 weeks of content to catch up on is you need the time to actually do that.

Here's a little secret, one of the things that makes since mailshot a little different to most weeklies is that I take the time to read/watch/listen to every single link I put in here, which when you add onto the time to actually gather these links together, and curate and select the best of the bunch you get a massive chunk of time.

Am I looking for sympathy? Nah, but if it does pluck at your heartstrings a little do me a favour and share this newsletter, forward the email round the office, give it to friends, repost the archived version off the site, send the site link around, share us on Twitter, retweet, share on Facebook/reddit etc.
Hell, print the issues out and stick them to a wall if that's your thing, but I'm always happy to get new subscribers as the current 433 readers (with at least 70% of you actually opening and reading each issue, damn those spam boxes), I'm always hoping to reach more people.

Or if that's too much effort, you can always just send me a link or to include in the mailout, you know, if you want. *puppy dog eyes*

News & announcements

PHP 5.5.0 Alpha4 released
Latest round of 5.5 alphas is ready to test (I actually missed the 3rd alpha with last weeks lack of an issue). See the news files for alpha3 and alpha4 for the downlow on new features and fixes.

PHP 5.4.11 and PHP 5.3.21 released
Bugfix-a-go-go for your server upgrade delights. Check the changelog for what's fixed.

Laravel 3.2 released
Some bug fixes, but also some great new features such as registration of custom drivers for different systems, e.g. caching, database etc.

Laravel 4 Beta 1 released
L4 is definitely shaping up, with far too any hot new features to list here, of particular note is the new documentation, and the fact that 4 is now the "develop" branch for Laravel, meaning new feature development work after the final release will go into 4.

PSR-3 accepted and ratified
The PHP-FIG have accepted the controversial PSR-3 which defines a standard Logging Interface that logging libraries can conform to if they want, making it easier for frameworks and other libraries to decouple themselves from any particular logging library as long as it implements the PSR3 interface. Love it or hate it, the marmite of the PHP standards world is here to stay.

 

Rasmus to give opening keynote at SunshinePHP
If the awesome line up and activities at the SunshinePHP conference in February weren't enough to entice you to buy a ticket, everyones favourite BDFL will be getting the show on the road, Mr Lerdorf is known for giving great talks so consider adding this event to your calendar.

Audiovisuals

Lately in PHP podcast: The Urge to Kill Older PHP Versions
Regular hosts Manuel Lemos, and making a welcome return after an internet-hiatus Ernani Joppert, talk shop about differing opinions in the community about deprecating and ultimately removing language features, have the efforts of the PHP-FIG gotten anywhere in 3 years, and Manuel's PHP Zeitgeist report.

Programming With Anthony - Iterators
Programming With Anthony - Mediators
Anthony Ferrara back with some well made video tutorials on PHP Iterators and the Mediator Pattern, with his usual hand-written examples and clear to understand style.

Better Workflow in PHP With Composer, Namespacing, and PHPUnit
A step by step video tutorial by Jeffrey Way on the current best practices with Composer, namespacing, unit tests and everything you should be doing if you're not already.

Articles

Partial mocks with Mockery
Simon Jodet manages to perfectly sum up my own feelings on mocking in PHPUnit and then goes on to (briefly) cover the new kid on the block atoum, but gets onto the main meat of his post, a good quickstart guide to partially mocking a class with my own favourite library Mockery.

An unexpected result from the PHP manual: odbc_setoption()
An extremely short and sweet post highlighting a humorous and apt quote from the PHP odbc extension manual pages. Made me .

Google's Two-Factor Auth - Online or Offline
Chris Cornutt, or PHPDeveloper.org fame, goes step by step through the process of using Google Authenticator for multi-factor auth using his GAuth library, available via Composer/Packagist, with some nice configuration examples.

Password Hashing with Zend\Crypt
Chris Cornutt again with a nice write up of using Zend\Crypt from ZF2 to create secure BCrypt hashes in your apps.

7php: Interview With Cal Evans
Khayrattee Wasseem back with another interview with a PHP community luminary, this time Cal Evans, master attendee of conferences, host of the brilliant Voices of the ElePHPant, ex-Zender, and prolific article writer to seriously name but a few. In Khayrattee's own words he's the icon of the community, so don't miss out on this great interview.

7php: Interview With Timothy Boronczyk
Khayrattee again with another interview (honestly, I don't know how he keeps up), with Timothy Boronczyk managing director of PHPMaster.com, and co-author of "Beginning PHP 6, Apache, MySQL 6 Web Development", which incidentally my wife used to get herself through a PHP course last year (when she wasn't asking me of course). Lots of good points made by Timothy, especially about PHP strengths (although I think Cal really nailed it in his interview with the community), and especially like his little emacs jab, as a vi[m] user myself.

Quick Debugging of PHP Scripts in Emacs with Geben and Xdebug
Speaking of emacs, Oracle's Christopher Jones gives us this quick step-by-step guide to getting xdebug debugging working in everyone's favourite LISP engine, ahem I mean editor.

A WebSockets, Ratchet, Silex and Redis pubsub implementation
James Morris needed to get a betting companies existing web app onto an iPhone, with realtime-or-bust speed, so polling a RESTful web service was out of the question. He ended up implementing a nice proof of concept using Ratchet and Silex to power a WebSocket connected event-driven app. If you're looking for solutions in this space and don't want to travel in Node.js territory, this might be for you.

PHP and webdriver – this time with a partial solution
Adam Goucher is a man on a mission, to get his fork of the webdriver bindings for PHP accepted as the defacto bindings by the community, and he a whole raft of reasons why we should take it seriously, along with putting his own money where his mouth is (well time, but as a consultant time=money).

Using PHP Data Objects
.net Magazine's Daniel Lewis brings us a simple guide to either using PDO for the first timer or switching your current database access to PDO. Nice and detailed with the usual mix of code and visuals.

Node.js for PHP Developers part #1-4
Interested in Node.js and asynchronous server-side JavaScript? Well Francois Zaninotto is here to the rescue, he's compiled a guide (now up to 4 parts, part 1 is here) detailing the different aspects of Node.js development and how you can relate and transition to them coming from PHP. PHPDeveloper.org has a summary and links to all 4 parts here.

PSR-Huh?
Elias Zerrouq gives us this summary of the PHP-FIG, what a PSR is, what the currently accepted PSR's are, why you should care, and various criticisms in the community, especially regards the recently accepted PSR-3.

Parsing and evaluating PHP in Haskell: Part 1
Parsing and evaluating PHP in Haskell: Part 2
Jani Hartikainen wanted to try writing a language parser in Haskell as an exercise, forgoing the obvious make-your-own-language and deciding to stick with another language he knew quite well, he decided on writing a PHP parser. This extremely well written and detailed 2 part (so far) series is not only a nice little intro to Haskell, but also for anyone interested in language parsing and why PHP is such a bloody hard language to parse (as static analyser writers have complained about for years).

How to Write an Operator Precedence Parser in PHP
A great article by Sherif Ramadan on operator precedence, the math and computer science behind figuring out precedence, and ultimately writing a parser for operator precedence in PHP, going from basic tokenisers through to lexers, and dealing with precedence overloading via parenthesis.

Functional programming in PHP
Lars Strojny gives us the skinny on function programming without breaking out the LISP or Haskell, using lambdas, closures and the great array of functional mapping builtin functions in PHP to avoid many common pitfalls of PHP dev by using a different coding paradigm.

PHP Mentoring and the Importance of the Software Apprenticeship
Elizabeth Smith brings us this weeks human interest story, so to speak, with a look at why mentoring aspiring PHP developers is so important, not just for the developer but for the mentor and the company as a whole. She's very passionate about the subject, and quite frankly I believe you should be too. Go on, read it and get involved, you know you want to.

Using Interfaces For Exceptions
Brandon Savage highlights some of the pitfalls when extending base Exception classes (such as Exception itself, or those in the SPL), how traits don't necessary help, and how he believes using interfaces is the best of both worlds.

Setting max_input_time (with data!)
Kevin Schroeder doesn't like letting so called conventional wisdom go without good reasons and more importantly real data. This time he tackles why some people suggest setting max_input_time (the time taken to parse a HTTP request body and querystring) to very large sizes. He has example code and benchmarks he ran in a small VM, along with results and some reasonable conclusions. The short of it is it depends on your use case, but if you only need to deal with small requests you can possibly protect yourself against some DoS attacks with a smaller time setting.

Zend Framework 2 Event Manager - A Gentle Introduction
Matthew Setter's gentle introduction to the EventManager in ZF2 (one of my favourite parts of the newly rebooted ZF), which drives much of the internals of ZF2, providing a event-driven interface to managing an app life cycle, as well as providing Observer and AOP style patterns. Matthew goes into a little bit of detail on why you should care and how you might use it in your own code.

Projects

atoum
Billed as a "A simple, modern and intuitive unit testing framework for PHP", this looks to provide a great alternative to the showing-it's-age PHPUnit.

Mobile-Detect
A simple library for detecting mobile devices based on HTTP request headers, such as the user-agent string.

PHP.rb
Actually a Ruby library that cross-compiles Ruby code to PHP. Why? Not a clue, but it's quite cool how it does using AST generation.

php-xxhash
A PHP extension that allows you to generate hashes using the blazingly-fast xxhash algorithm, highly useful if you're in an environment were speed matters, such as realtime streams.

csswizardry/fluid-grids
Ex-colleague of mine and CSS wizard (although I've never seen him wear his hat or get out his wand) Harry Roberts released this code for generating fluid grid designs from PHP, and has asked for feedback, pull requests and forks to make it better.

semver
Semantic Versioning is wonderful and pretty much supported by anything that needs to care about versions (including Composer). This small library allows you to parse and compare semantic versions with a nice API.

Isolator
This neat little library provides you with a proxy object that you can inject into your own objects and use to call PHP builtin functions, then during testing you can tell the proxy to mock out selective function calls rather than calling the actual builtin. Handy.

cosmos
Cosmos is a library for parsing and manipulating PHP classnames and namespace paths, which can be helpful if you want to map canonical class names (e.g. MyRouterClass) to actual importable classes or objects (e.g. \MyLibrary\Helpers\Routing\MyRouterClass).

Ubiq
Ubiq provides different methods for manipulating and parsing strings with a very readable API.

JQJobs
A lightweight asynchronous job queue manager written in PHP, similar to beanstalk, with (obviously) full PHP stack integration.

kumite
A library for managing multi-variate (such as A/B) testing from your PHP, from start (splitting users up based on criteria) to finish (gathering the results of the test).

Datum
Another DateTime extension with expressive object orientated range APIs.

Iniliq
An INI config file parser that unlike the PHP builtin parsing functions allows for multiple file inheritance, subfield values and selectors, and JSON value support.

Negotiation
Negotiation allows you to easily implement content negotiation in your app, e.g. returning different values based on supported client features and other HTTP goodness.

— Brian Muse (@briancmuse) January 24, 2013

Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #6 for Thursday the 10th of January 2013

Haters gonna hate

Not much to say on my soapbox this week, other than we're gearing up for conference time, so remember to get those talk proposals submitted, those tickets booked and those geekbags packed.

In other news it seems the past week has been particularly incendiary in not just the PHP community but all parts of the tech community.
With that in mind, here's a puppy:


Correction: last week I accidentally typo'd the new owners of php|a as Musketeers.com when it's really Musketeers.me. Oops, sorry.

News & announcements

Symfony 2.2.0 Beta 1 released
Lots of new and shiny features in 2.2, it looks like beta 1 introduces a feature freeze, so time to get testing, see the schedule for newness and an idea when to expect a stable release.

APC 3.1.14 released
The defacto PHP opcode cache has been bumped to 3.1.14, still in a beta state, but this release adds 5.5 support so perfect for testing with the new 5.5 alphas. Check out the changelog for more.

 

Audiovisuals

A Look Back on PHP 5.5 Development in 2012
This is a video visualisation of PHP 5.5 activity in the past year by one of the core devs, shown by displaying branch nodes representing source control branches and their committers, with nodes branching off and merging back in again. Take a look at gource if you're interested in making these videos yourself.

Programming with Anthony - Dependency Injection
Another excellent video tutorial by Anthony Ferrara, this time covering Dependency Injection, and to a lesser degree Inversion of Control, in PHP in Anthony's charming hand-drawn notes style.

Articles

PHP needs a vision
There's been a bit of a storm in a teacup again on the PHP internals mailing list, sparked off by a discussion about introducing proper annotations to the language (not just docblock parsing), and frankly some people getting their nickers in a twist. Linking to the HN page for this as there's been some good comments on there (just ignore the generic PHP hate that always comes with a HN discussion).

2012: A Year in PHP
Ben Longden looks back at his predictions from last year, going over hits and misses, and what he reckons 2013 might have in store. Some good points, especially regards improvements in PHP and community outlooks this past year, and solid predictions for the coming year.

Избавляемся от дублирования сквозного кода в PHP: рефакторинг кода с АОП
A very nice write-up (in Russian) by Лисаченко Александрon on using the Aspect Orientated Programming pattern in PHP in order to de-duplicate code across a project. He covers various different techniques such as proxy objects, signalling, and rounds out the first introductory part of this series (hopefully) with using the Go! library to implement AOP in PHP.

SunshinePHP is a community event
The guys behind SunshinePHP reply to recent misrepresentation of the conference as a commercial event, in their own words it is by developers, for developers, and all profits from the conference will go 100% into the user group and PHP community. So there, no go sign up. ;)

Why is FastCGI /w Nginx so much faster than Apache /w mod_php?
Kevin Schroeder takes the oft heard assertion "PHP is faster on Nginx + FastCGI" by running the actual numbers and tracing Apache to see why so many people might be seeing worse performance in Apache+mod_php. The answer probably won't surprise you, but the fact Apache+mod_php actually outperforms Nginx with the right configuration might do, read on for some good advice.

7php Interviews With Ligaya Turmelle Co-Founder Of PHPwomen.org
Khayrattee Wasseem back with another great interview with a PHP luminary (wasn't it just yesterday the last one way out?), this time Ligaya Turmelle of phpwomen.org fame, discussing everything from her first steps into PHP to her huge contributions to and involvement with the PHP community on whole. My favourite part is Ligaya remeniscing about an embarrassing email send test back at her old company, because I've been that exact same person (as I'm sure many of you have) before and can now laugh at it looking back.

PHP Apps and Platform as a Service
Andy Podner with a good write up of deploying your first PHP app to AppFog, the multi-language/enviroment Platform as a Service (PaaS) provider, complete with handy step by step guide, and comparison with other PaaS/IaaS providers with PHP offerings.

We are all PHP Evangelists
Rafael Dohms reposted his php|a article from last year in which he recounts a lovely little true story about a time in the Brazilian PHP community when everyone banded together to get some harmful misinformation spread by a TV station redacted and corrected. Good stuff and some truly heartfelt and true words on community.

reddit: Your prediction for PHP in 2013?
Does what it says on the tin: a reddit discussion of peoples predictions for the next year, some funny, some earnest, some best just glossed over.

Projects

php-cliopts
Billed as a no-nonsence command line options parser, nice and simple API.

AsymetriCrypt
A promising asymetric public/private key encryption library, no docs as yet but some easy to understand examples.

CalendR
An OO PHP calendar management library, allows you define calendar functions and manage date/time based events, one to watch.

Bob
A tiny and messy build build tool for PHP much in the same vein as Pake or Phing but without a lot of hassle (no XML and a cleaner API than Pake), which is actually something I'd considered making myself, and the perfect companion for Composer.

itertools
Reminiscent of itertools in Python-land this is a well defined library of utility functions for dealing with iterables in PHP and making them as useful as the all powerful Array.

Phinx
A database migration management library, allows you to define RDBMS independent data/schema migrations. +1!

Phue
Ever wanted to control the hue and illumination level of the lighting in your house from PHP? No? Well tough, because now you can, if you have a Philips Hue lighting system and this library that is.

Geocoder
A geocoding abstraction library with support multiple geo-aware API providers, so your app can know where the user is when they post pictures of kittens with funny captions.

howdoi
Actually an app written in Python, but a damn handy utility for PHP devs. To show what it does I'll give you an example instead:
$ howdoi reverse an array php
$newArray = array_reverse($theArray, true);

item.title: Issue #5 for Thursday the 3rd of January 2013
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #5 for Thursday the 3rd of January 2013

It's 2013, where's my damn jetpack?

Another rotation round the sun and another PHP Weekly for inbox.
If you thought the festive week itself was quiet, then New Years was practically silent, but fear not intrepid reader there a few morsels to wet your appetite for the year ahead.

As everyone seems to be blogging about their New Years Resolutions, but no one ever follows through with them, here are some New Year Suggestions:
  • Release more code.
  • Submit some talk proposals.
  • Be excellent [to each other].

News & announcements

Pop PHP Framework 1.1.1 released
Some CSRF/Captcha form changes and a request parsing method added, see the changelog for more details..

Articles

12 TDDs of Christmas
John Cleary set himself the challenge of doing a test-driven-development kata a day (from the 26th of December), and encouraged other to join along on Twitter with the hashtag #12TDDs, it looks like it was a smashing success and some interesting solutions produced by people too.

Become a ZCE in 2013
Lorna Mitchell is encouraging you to make 2013 the year to become a Zend Certified Engineer, and she throws up plenty of resources to help get you there (some free, some cheap). I've been a ZCE since 2007 and I'd strongly suggest looking into it.

PHP equal operator ==
Gynvael Coldwind gives us this very thorough and in-depth write up of what actually happens when you compare the different internal types and user defined objects with the double equals (==) operator, tip: it may not always do what you think it will.

7php: Interview With Musketeers.me On Taking Over PHP|Architect – Goal Is To Make Existing Processes More Efficient With Fresh Bloods
Khayrattee Wasseem is back with another great interview with PHP community luminaries, this time with the new owners of php|a the team from Musketeers, on their motivation for taking over from Mark Tabini and co, the challenges of taking on an already established property with such a solid community standing, and what's in store for the magazine in the future.

Why Lithium is Worth a Look
Andy Podner was a man with a plan - rewriting an older project as a standalone app to expand into something else in 2013 - but what framework to use? Deciding to use the new year to explore something new he gave Lithium a try, making sure it has support for all the development tools and practices he relies on in CodeIgniter. A good write up with both pros and cons of using Lithium.

SOLID - The D is for Dependency Inversion Principle
Freek Lijten with a nice overview of Dependency Inversion Priciple, a development practice which avoids replication and reduction of untestable/unmockable code by defining known interfaces for objects and using dependency injection for each usable component, which means you can write, use and test the API for application and it's components, not the algorithms and business logic within.

Getting off the island in 2013
Larry Garfield put out this call to the Drupal community to get off the island in 2013, and by that he means the inclusive Drupal-only-or-GTFO island that is slowly emptying by way of using non-Drupal modules (via Composer, 'natch) in Drupal itself, and steadily releasing decoupled Drupal code to the wider community, but he wants to see more. Drupal devs attending non-Drupal conferences, interacting with the wider PHP community and wider web dev community, giving back and bringing in more wisdom to Drupal. Many other projects and communities with inclusive mindsets could do to take note of this excellent advice.

Symfony Components: Sometimes Decoupled, Sometimes Not
Paul M Jones runs down the good guys, bad guys and anti-heroes of decoupled components in Symfony2. It still stands that some components are completely decoupled and can be used at will in your apps, but 4 core components aren't decoupled at all and have mandatory requirements, while Paul reckons 5 components have a debatable decoupled status at the very least.

Creating a PHP OAuth Server
A solid tutorial by Jamie Munro on creating an OAuth 1.0a provider using oauth-php, from using Composer to install it manually from Google Code (in lieu of an actual package on Packagist) to setting up the necessary MySQL schema, HTML forms and PHP controllers.

First Impressions: Cloud9 IDE + PHP
James Fuller wrote up his first impression of using the PHP integration in the excellent Cloud9 IDE (which you may recognise in a small part from using the integrated ACE editor on GitHub), with a similar conclusion to my own, including the shortcomings (especially as a fellow vim user).

Personal Thoughts On The PSR-3 Log Proposal
Stuart Herbert weighs in on the polarising PSR-3 debate with his personal thoughts on the matter, in short he isn't against the LoggerInterface standard, he just thinks the standard could be a lot better and in his post details how he'd like to see the proposal improved.

PHP CLI usage survery
A very short survey by Tom Hudson on developer PHP CLI usage (e.g. development of command line apps with PHP), he already had a pretty big response, but take a minute to fill it out so he can get an even bigger picture.

Projects

serverdensity/mendedstring
Some blatant self-promotion with this one as I just released this code on New Years Day based on migration code I wrote at SD a year ago. The MendedString class allows you to detect and decode single byte encoded multi byte strings, e.g. UTF-8 characters encoded (even multiple times) with utf8_encode. I'll be releasing a blog post soon on why we needed this and how we used it.

Patchwork
A library that uses stream handlers in PHP >=5.3 to allow you to override user functions, ala the runkit extension using pure PHP code. Use with caution, but it just might be that magic bullet you need to test an external library you don't have control over and can't using dependency injection with.

jyggen/curl
A lightweight cURL wrapper with multiple request support. Could be handy if you don't need the full power of Guzzle.\

lootils/geo
Library for dealing with geodetic calculations, for example finding the distance between 2 points on the earth.

snowscript
Another language that cross-compiles to PHP, inspired by Python, Lua, Coffescript, Go and Scala.

PHP-Parser
A PHP (<=5.4) parser written in PHP, with the aim of making static code analysis/manipulation easier to implement and execute.

pChart

A very nice little, and elegant, toolkit for creating command line apps. Nice to have something similar to Clint in PHP-land.

item.title: Issue #4 for Thursday the 27th of December 2012
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #4 for Thursday the 27th of December 2012

Here's to the last issue before 2013 \m/

Apologies for the delay in getting this issue out, been a bit of a mess with a bout of manflu.

Well here we are, 4 issues in, the last issue of the year, 350+ subscribers, and many more to come.
It's been a rather quiet week in PHP-land, with the festive season and all, but with some PHP releases last week and people ending the year with bits and pieces, we have a little something for everyone.

News & announcements

PHP 5.4.10 and PHP 5.3.20 released!
The PHP team announced these bugfix releases just after the last issue went to press so speak, check out the changelog for  full list of fixes. Hint: there's a fair few and you'll want to upgrade when you can.

PHP 5.5.0 Alpha2 released
Another 5.5 alpha out the door with even more features to try out, like the new empty and isset functionality I covered 2 issues ago in RFCorner, or the ability to trace program execution using systemtap. See the NEWS file for a full list.

 

Symfony 2.0.20 and 2.1.5 released
(and was followed up almost immediately by)
Symfony 2.0.21 and 2.1.6 being released
These releases fix 2 exploitable routing issues, including bypassing protections on internal controllers.

24 Pull Requests finishes on a high note
Revisiting this project I've previously mentioned as they finish off the season with "3068 pull requests to 1462 different open source projects".

Audiovisuals

PHP Town Hall - The EE revolt of 2012 and why you should unit-test your [stuff]
Ben Edmunds and Phil Sturgeon back with another excellent episode of the PHP Town Hall podcast, this time joined by ExpressionEngine pro Anna Brown and "Testing Hero" Chris Hartjes, discussing the various rumblings in the EE community over the past year, and relatedly the formation of the ExpressionEngine StackExchange community support site. Of particular noteworth is the discussion with Chris about Inversion of Control and it's powerful use in unit tests.
(Slightly NSFW, avoid if you don't like sweary).

Cloud Out Loud - Future of PHP Part I: ZF2
EngineYard's David Shafik interviews Zend Framework core devs Evan Coury, Ralph Schindler, Matthew O'Phinney and Rob Allen, discussing ZF2 features, adoption, the future of ZF releases and Zend Framework 1 maintenance with thousands of developers and companies making a living off the existing stable base. A favourite part of the panel's discussion for me was about EventManager and how ZF2 effectively went the JS model route for events within the framework - this is something a lot of projects are doing as it's an easy model to get your head around, especially if you've already done JS work.

Cloud Out Loud - Future of PHP Part II: CakePHP
David Shafik, again, interviews core CakePHP devs (and fans) Mary Story, José Lorenzo and Larry Masters, discussing the future of CakePHP, v3 features and adoption, work with the PHP-FIG. Listen in for a special announcement.

Articles

7php interviews Matthew Weier O’Phinney Project Lead of Zend Framework
Khayrattee Wasseem back with his 21st interview with a PHP luminary, this time Matthew Weier O'Phinney of ZF fame, with a typically huuuuge discussion (I'm only just over half way through it myself) about Matthew's programmer beginning's, his likes and dislikes about PHP, the community, working for Zend, and other topics from his IDE (a vim guy after my own heart) to design patterns. Look out for one of the best pieces of advice a beginner developer, or any developer, can receive.

A Response To "On php-fig and Shared Interfaces"
Paul M. Jones responds to Matthew Weier O'Phinney's post (in which he weighs in on the subject of the PHP-FIG proposing Shared Interfaces as a standard for library interoperability) explaining how he sees no disadvantages to interfaces (such as those for a Cache util or a Logging util) being codified as a PSR, and only advantages for any project that wishes to use them (as with PSR[0-2]).
Matthew also provided a response in the comments.

One logger to rule them all
Jordi Boggiano of Composer and Packagist fame puts forward his 2-pence on the Shared Interfaces discussion, this time from the point of view of framework developers and packaging (naturally). This one definitely seems to be polarising people!

Composer: a evolução PHP
A nice round up by Tárcio Zemel on the advantages of using Composer in your projects, along with a quick guide to making your first package. (Yes, it's Portuguese, deal with it.)

CodeIgnitor: Keeping M-V-C straight
Andy Podner gives a quick overview of what-is-what in CodeIgnitor Models, Controllers and Views.

What's New in Zend Framework 2
Aurelio De Rosa has a smashing write up of the new features and changes in ZF2, I've already said EventManager is one of my favourites, but my second favourite is the shift towards using Inversion of Control in whole the new components, click through to find out more.

Cooperative multitasking using coroutines (in PHP!)
Nikita Popov gifts us with a brilliant write up with practical examples of using co-routines in PHP using the new generators syntax coming in 5.5. Co-routines are effectively co-operative tasks which work by swapping running functions in and out of the stack, given a particular break condition (e.g. the yield statement), and they've popular in multi-tasking systems like Python's Gevent, Ruby's EventMachine and pretty everywhere in Node.js. Most of the examples Nikita shows are a still a little too cumbersome for real world use, but the possibilities are there, especially for non-blocking I/O operations.

Microsoft drops Expression Web
I'm not a Windows guy myself but I've had friends say that Microsoft Expression Web is actually a very good PHP IDE, which seems to have been reflected in the effort they've put into PHP cons over the last so many years. They have however decided to can the Expression series of apps and roll them up into Visual Studio, unfortunately it looks like the good PHP editing/debugging features are only provided by third party add-ons.

Create an address book with PHP and MongoDB
Lorna Jane Mitchell and Steve Francia wrote this nice little tutorial for .NET Magazine on creating a simple address book app that for the beginner (either with PHP and/or Mongo) produces a useful bit of code out the other end.

Projects

ev
libev wrapper PECL extension which brings high performance event loops to PHP. I'd love to see someone combine ev with coroutines in 5.5.

Kunststube\POTools
A collection of utils for working with gettext PO files, not fully featured yet but showing lots of promise in the API.

coseva
A nice little library for parsing and filtering CSV data with a fully OO interface.

ppi
ppi is a simple and flexible framework that utilises the best components for each job from ZF2, Symfony2 and Doctrine2.

Canoma
A completely backend agnostic consistent hashing utility, allows you to use consistent and replicable hashes for caching in your application.

item.title: Issue #3 for Thursday the 20th of December 2012
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #3 for Thursday 20th of December 2012

In which news is slow but articles are goooood

As we get closer to the festive season proper news and links are beginning to thin out, but quality is an all time high (well for this lists short 3 week life time that is).

I generally encourage everyone to tweet my personal account on Twitter, and follow me if you're that way inclined, but I know my tweets aren't for everyones tastes, being sometimes personal, sometimes about politics, humour, or just non-PHP tech (e.g. Python, JavaScript, DevOps etc.).
With that in mind I created @PHPWeekly in which I will retweet any list related nuggets (new issue announcements for example).

With the 25th being next week (you know, that day involving mince pies) don't expect much in the way of PHP related content, but I will endeavour to get the next issue out as usual on Thursday.
On that note there'll be no RFCs round up this week, partly so I can have a longer section to fill in some content next week, and partly because I seem to be coming down with a cold. *sneeze*

News & announcements

Zend Framework 2.0.6 released
"This release includes almost 60 patches, ranging from minor docblock improvements to complete bugfixes."

Zend Framework 1.11.15 and 1.12.1 released
These are security fix releases for potential exploit found in Zend_Feed_Rss and Zend_Feed_Atom - even if you don't use these classes directly you should still update now in case you rely on anything with a dependency on them or do so in the future.

Wordpress 3.5 "Elvin" released
The biggest change in this fresh release of the defacto blogging app is a reimplemented and smoother photo/media uploading process, an updated default theme and lots of UX tweaks.

Musketeers.me to acquire php|architect’s brand and products effective January 1st
A heartfelt announcement by Marco Tabini on how far he and the team have come with php|a over the past 10 years (as it really been that long? I remember my first subscription dropping through the letterbox like it was yesterday) and how they feel it's time to move on but not without leaving the magazine and accompanying works (books, training, events etc.) in very good community-focussed hands.

php[tek] 2013 announced, and call for papers!
Despite everyone wondering if there would even be a php[tek] next year it turns out things had just been a bit busy at the php|a offices with the above brand changeover news, php[tek] will be back and bigger than ever. No signups yet but they have a CFP out, so get those talk proposals submitted (before Jan 15th).

MongoDB PHP Driver 1.3.2 released

Aura fullstack 1.0.0-beta4 released

Audiovisuals

Voices of the ElePHPant: Interview with Chris Spruck, Kevin Roberts, and Nic Rosental
Cal Evans is back for another excellent podcast, this time featuring a roundtable discussion with PHP Atlanta user group organisers Chris Spruck, Kevin Roberts and Nic Rosental discussing amongst other things the huge success of PHP Atlanta, it's blowout 100th meeting, and the intricacies of what works and doesn't work when organising UGs.


Articles

On Libraries and Dependencies
Bernhard Schussek addresses the recent spate of posts on how framework components, such as Aura should not have dependencies, and with it even more articles and opinion pieces saying that dependencies are a bad thing. Bernhard rightly puts this hogwash to bed before everyone gets all Not Invented Here, as projects like Guzzle and Laravel have recently shown dependencies on existing well written packages are a good thing and with Composer inclusion and use of such packages is practically painless.

A Response to "Micro-Optimizations in PHP"
A detailed response by Jason McCreary, to an earlier linked to article on micro-optimisations, debunking in turn each myth and wrong assumption made. For more information on the single quotes vs double quotes myth Nikita Popov wrote an excellent piece earlier in the year.

Tweetable PHP Non-Alpha
and PHP  non alpha numeric 7 and 6 char code
A very fun couple of posts, by Gareth Heyes and Alex Inführ respectively, on writing PHP code using non-alphanumeric character sets and language tricks. Most of these only work in PHP >= 5.4, but they're very cool from a..well..that's quite cool standpoint, you'd probably never use any of the tricks but it's good as an intellectual exercise to understand them in the context of the language.

Seven Ways To Screw Up BCrypt
List favourite Anthony Ferrara gives a nice rundown of common and some not-so-common pitfalls when generating BCrypt hashes in your application, e.g. for passwords. I particularly liked using versions of PHP with fallbacks if bcrypt  support isn't compiled in and the bonus guarding against timing attacks.

Multiple inheritance with PHP and Traits
Gonzalo Ayuso's post shows how you can kinda do multiple inheritance using PHP 5.4's traits feature, with a good description of what traits are and aren't, and how to use them without method and property collisions.

Timezones, the Right Way
A well written piece on getting those tricky little buggers timezones right in your app. I don't know a single dev who likes working with timezones or the annoyances that go with them, but there is some good solid advice in this article from setting a default timezone and storing all your dates in UTC, to some well thought out [My]SQL queries.

What to Expect From PHP 5.5
Another article on the hotness coming in 5.5, this time from Gabriel Manricks. If you've followed my previous mailshots you'll probably know all these, but Gabriel gives a very thurough write up and covers the lesser known cURL tweaks coming in 5.5, and small but lovely addition of ["const", "and", "string dereferencing"][1].

The Three Ugly Sisters
Pádraic Brady with a brilliant piece of Web Advent on what he terms the Three Ugly Sisters or in other words 3 different classes of security exploit which he's tried to highlight over the year, including Peerjacking, XML injection and our old friend XSS. With each description he includes examples of the wrong way to do it in PHP and how to get it right.

Composer, Github and Travis-CI
A quick and simple post by one of the guys at EasyBib on how they use Composer with Travis-CI to test code on GitHub repos using a stored token. This is similar to how we're doing builds at SD but follow the words of caution closely and don't accidentally leak GitHub tokens in your public repos!

Continuous Deployment Practices
Continuing my practice of ending this section with a not-strictly-PHP entry, another WebAdvent post this time by community-fave Laura Thomson on a subject close to my heart: Continuous Deployment. Laura goes through some of what she considers best practices (and I agree, in some cases I'd say requirements, but that ones a touchy subject). Great advice all round and if you're not doing this then you should..well..you should look into it, anyway. Remember if in doubt just ship it!

Projects

simple-serializer
A nice and simple JSON serializer/deserializer API for handling objects given configuration on how to handle non-JSON-native types.

lf5php
A framwork for creating logging framework facades, or wrappers, so that you can use a different logging mechanism as a backend but access the logging through the same interface, e.g. $logger->info('Info yo!');

xmldsig
A library for handling XML Digital Signatures in PHP.

phpctagger
A utility for generating ctags from a Composer package or project, which you can then use where ever you can use ctags, like in your IDE of choice (and have the unique symbols for the package recognised by the editors highlighting and autocompletion).

PHPHandles
A wrapper around the V8 JavaScript engine and Handlebars.js for generating content from Handlebars templates on the server-side.

Expressive Date
A simple little extension to the inbuilt DateTime class which adds fluent access to methods.

Throttle
A simple library for limiting a function call based on calls within a set time period.

Popcorn
A micro-framework for creating RESTful webservices, based on the Pop framework.

ServeMI
A nice idea that has been done before in other languages and frameworks: take a command line utility, stick a simple PHP script with a given API in front of it, et voila you can now access the util via HTTP. No license or much docs (yet) but interesting to see as a concept.

Pharen
Ever wished you could write your apps in LISP-like syntax and then have it compiled to PHP to run on your server? Well, umm, me either, but Tamreen Khan did and he's done some interesting things with it.

item.title: Issue #2 for Thursday the 13th of December 2012
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #2 for Thursday the 13th of December 2012

Another issue, Just In Time

Well I must say the PHP community is making it both a joy and a labour to make these weeklies, with tonnes of articles, projects and discussions just flying around in the past week.

Someone emailed to ask if I'm okay with sharing these issues with friends and coworkers - well, yah please do. In fact if you look at the bottom of this email I now release each one under a permissive Creative Commons license, which means you're not just free to share but edit and re-share to your hearts content.
Each issue is also archived here in perpetuity.

I'd also like to take a moment to thank my new sponsor (who also happen to be my employer) Server Density, who are making sure I can keep sending these out no matter how many of you sign up. :)

News & announcements

Rasmus asks for help QAing PHP 5.5
<lordkitchner>PHP5.5 Alpha1 needs you!</lordkitchner>
And Rasmus would really like it if you helped too.

PHPClasses.org announce new karma-like rewards system
Manuel Lemos tells us all about the new system he's put into the site (and also to JS Classes) providing developers who submit code and contribute via the community to gain levels of membership and other bonuses. In his own words "I did not want PHP Classes to be yet another site giving stinking badges."

MongoDB 1.3.1 PHP driver released

Symfony 2.2 set for release January 6th 2013

 

PHP The Right Way translated into Bulgarian

Audiovisuals

Lately in PHP discuss PHP possibly getting JIT compilation and more
Regular host Manuel Lemos and guest host César Rodas discuss the latest round of discussions in the PHP core dev team about adding JIT compilation to PHP itself, inspired by Facebook's HipHop VM. Although the general consensus is that HipHop will never be merged into PHP, but some of the devs are interested in implementing LLVM based JIT. Exciting stuff. No, really. The usual roundup of PHP news was also discussed, including Manuel's own PHPClasses and JSClasses sites getting their new karma systems.

PHP Town Hall talk about upcoming features in PHP 5.5
Episode #2 of this nicely produced podcast (which somehow managed to slip under my radar until this last week) features regular host Phil Sturgeon is joined by community stalwarts Zack Kitzmiller, John Crepezzi and Anthony Ferrera, or in their own words "a Node Hipster, Beardy Python Fan, PHP Contributor and a Bristolian" discussing some of the kinky new features in PHP 5.5, and how they compare with similar features in other languages.

Articles

Debugging Connections with the MongoDB PHP driver
Derick Rethans continues his excellent series of blog posts on working with the MongoDB 1.3 PHP driver. In this article he covers the great new debugging and logging features for fixing a wonky connection to Mongo, including the vastly new and improved MongoLog class.

How Is Aura Better Than (er, Different From ;-) Than Symfony and Zend?
Paul M Jones posted this English translation of his email interview with PHP Magazin all about, you guessed it, the Aura framework's advantages over Symfony 2 and Zend Framework 2, including the decision to make Aura PHP 5.4+ only.

Aura: More Decoupled Than Symfony 2 and Zend Framework 2
In this follow up post Paul M Jones goes into the nitty gritty of using the various Aura classes outside of the framework and just how much more decoupled they are than the classes in Symfony 2 and Zend Framework 2 (both of which known for being highly decoupled from their core components, hence their use in other frameworks like Laravel).

Community News: Privates - Harmful or Useful?
The brilliant PHPDeveloper (if you don't read it, go subscribe now) covers the latest back and forth across the PHP community about use of private properties and methods in class designer, originally sparked off by this post by Brandon Savage.

9 Magic Methods in PHP
Lorna Mitchell gives a nice overview of 9 of the many magic methods in PHP 5.x from ye olde constructor to lesser used serialisation and object copying hooks.

Adding DTrace Probes to PHP Extensions
Following on from David Soria Parra's post on tracing PHP code using systemtap on Linux, this post by Oracle's Christopher Jones goes over the steps for building PHP with DTrace probe support and creating trace files for C extensions.

PHPitfalls
A nice article covering security steps and considerations when designing your PHP application for public use. A few points are a little dated (e.g. only mentioning the mysqli extnesion and not PDO) but some good points overall with solid recommendations like profiling the whatsits out of your code and this gem: 
"Rule 1 of input data hygiene: Nuke it from orbit, it’s the only way to make sure!"

Array Union Operator
Fabian Blechschmidt talks about the little-known array union operator, or as you-may-or-may-not know it the plus sign (+), and use-cases, in particular using it to fix a bug in the Magento Mage_Core_Helper_Data::removeAccents method.

Performance Calendar: Using NGINX, PHP-FPM+APC and Varnish to make WordPress Websites fly
A thorough write up by Tobias Baldauf on his Nginx+PHP-FPM+APC+Varnish stack tweaked to rafters for Wordpress, but plenty of pointers for PHP app stacks in general, especially the Nginx and PHP-AFM configs.

Build Automation with Composer Scripts
Good overview by Ignatius Teo of Composer's script hooks with an eye on automating build tasks by running scripts at different point during projection installation/update/uninstall. Some good pointers here on achieving the sort of things you might normally use Phing or Pake for, but with the awesome of Composer.

Le renouveau de PHP (English: The revival of PHP)
A French post by Clement Herreman on the various advances in both PHP itself, and supporting PHP projects like frameworks and Composer, that make developing in PHP fun again, or in his own words "rendant de nouveau le développement en PHP rapide, agréable et fiable".

Bug #63353APC opcode size/memory use under PHP 5.4 is radically lower than 5.3?
As Rasmus put it "It's nice when our optimizations confuse people to the point of filing bugs". 'nuff said.

Web Advent 2012
A web development article every day over the festive season, many of which PHP related.

Projects

Guzzle
This is an HTTP client library, reminiscent of requests in Python-land, with an elegant API that lends itself perfectly to working with RESTful webservices.

ErrorExceptions
A nice example of the power of PHPs error handlers which allows you to catch and handle system errors such as E_ERROR, E_WARNING, E_NOTICE etc. as real exceptions. By author Anthony Ferrara's own admission probably not production suitable, hey there's not even a license, but a good example of what can be done.

Leggio
A markdown based static blog generator, ala Jekyll, but with plans to be even more feature loaded and powerful.

Ray.Di
This dependency injection library is fork/extension of Aura.Di adds Guice-style (a Java dependency injection framework) DI to your PHP projects.

phpDaemon
An old and well established project that implements co-operative asynchronous long running PHP processes using non-blocking callbacks, ala Node.js, Gevent, etc. with a worker model ala Erlang and Go. Very interesting project that's worth a look if you want to implement something like a websocket server but don't want to use a mixed platform.

tinyl10n
Handy util for detecting the user's locale based on HTTP headers.

Msgfmt
A class based .po files to .mo file (used in i18n translations) converter based on Joss Crowcroft's original php.mo implementation.

goodby/csv
A memory efficient evented CSV file parser that reads a CSV file line by line and performs operations based on the line, like SAX parsing but CSVs, and with nice multibyte support so it won't choke on those UTF-x chars.

 

RFCorner

A quick glance at some of the features and changes considered for PHP via RFCs.

Autoboxing
Under discussion, this is a suggestion to add a new magic function __autobox which would be called at runtime whenever a primitive type, .e.g integer, string, boolean, etc. is accessed like an object, this function if provided by the user would return an object wrapper, written by the user, allowing you to treat the primitive as an object with methods and properties, e.g. imagine popping a value off an array by calling $array->pop(). Looks like this idea has mostly garnered nays from core devs due to the possibility for cross-project conflicts, lack of consideration for the Spl objects already provided, and possible slow downs caused by it.

Jsonable Interface
In the works, this is one of those ideas which you've probably hit on yourself if you've ever tried json_encode-ing an Object. The gist of it is to add a Jsonable interface which your class can implement and provide a __toJson magic method which would return a base type like a string or array etc. that can encoded safely by json_encode, and whenever you pass an instance of the class to json_encode, yep you guessed it, the magic method would be called and it would all just work. ++good. No patch as yet but doesn't look like there's any objections, so fingers crossed for a future release like 5.6.

Allow arbitrary expression arguments to empty() and isset()
Coming in 5.5, this simple feature allows empty() and isset() to accept non-variable expressions, e.g. the result of an inline like ($foo + $bar)/6 or a function/method call (with the return value being passed directly to empty or isset for testing).

Upcoming events

PHP Master Series vol 1
December 21st 2012
Can't make it to a PHP conference? Too expensive? Can't do the travel? For whatever reason how cool would it be if there was a major PHP con that was held completely online, were you could attend via webinars and online tools? Well look no further, PHP Master Series is the first in a (hopefully) long series of fully online conferences featuring some great talks and events, with a temptingly low ticket price.
PHPDeveloper.org have a good roundup of PHP-MSv1 resources.

Laracon
February 22nd-23rd 2013
Laravel really is becoming a big name in PHP frameworks and to prove it the project is hosting it's first 2 day community event in Washington DC. Some big sponsors and well known known devs have already signed up to help so if you're into Laravel already and fancy getting a foot in the door, check it out maybe?

Find a PHP User Group near you!

item.title: Issue #1 for Thursday the 6th of December 2012
item.description:
Fresh PHP linkage from the sofa of Wes Mason. Back to the archive.

PHP Weekly

Issue #1 for 6th December 2012

Well, that escalated quickly

When I first announced my desire to curate a weekly PHP related newsletter I expected a couple of signups, perhaps a pity-subscribe or two from friends, but I never imagined the fantastic response I got, picking up over 200 subscriptions before the first weekend had passed.
Wow.

My sincere thanks to everyone reading this inaugural issue, I wouldn't be doing this if not for you and the great community that surrounds PHP and makes it such a comfy place to develop, learn and share.

A few people have asked me if they can help out with the weekly and if so what can they do?
What can you do?
Go and make something! Make anything, it doesn't have to be cool, but if you pour a little bit of time, effort and your amazing mind into it you'll find it probably is rather cool.
Go forth, make things, share your knowledge, help others, cast your code to the wind, and use a nice license. It'll make my job so much easier, and it'll make the community a better place to boot.

News & announcements

PHP 5.4.9 and PHP 5.3.19 released
Lots of bug fixes, some minor, some stability and security related, to the package repositories boy wonder!

PHP 5.5.0 Alpha1 released
5.5 is nearly upon us, why not help shake out all the creepy crawlies and test the alpha? Keep reading for a discussion of new features and changes coming to 5.5 in RFCorner.

Aura framework releases stable 1.0.0
Aura is a PHP 5.4+ only framework with some really nice features, clean codebase, first rate Composer/Packagist support and a thriving community of devs. They just hit their first 1.0.0 stable release and going strong, check them out.

Package statistics added to Packagist
Everyone's favourite Composer package repository recently added detailed graphs and statistics for packages being added and updated.

Symfony 2.0.9 and 2.1.4 security releases

Zend Framework 2.0.5 security (and minor fixes) release

 

Audiovisuals

Programming with Anthony: PHP references (video)
Sent to me by a non-programmer friend this quirky video is the third in a series of programming explanations for beginners and novices. Anthony Ferrara records his hand drawn notes as he takes them, with a clear voice over explanation, in this instance going into a nifty description of references and copy-on-write pseudo-references in PHP 5.x - probably old hat to many like myself but if you haven't come across it before have a look.

Voices of the ElePHPant podcast interviews..
..with Moses Ngone
..and Mike Dawidowicz
If you've not come across Voices of the ElePHPant before stop what you're doing and get thee to a podcast-subscribing-thingumie. Cal Evans interviews, mostly every week, a different person of interest in the PHP community, from user group organisers, to prominent project developers, core developers and more. His recent interviews with user group leaders are especially good for insights into the intricacies of getting a local user group off the ground and supporting a small community.

Lately in PHP podcast: Should PHP be copying Java?
As well as the usual round up of PHP news regular host Manuel Lemos and guest Michael Kimsal discussed the often polarised discussion of PHP borrowing more from the Java world, including features and practices, spurred on by the recently rejected proposal to introduce Java-like generics to PHP.

Articles

Speeding up PHP-based development with HipHop VM
The clever chaps at Facebook's engineering dept. have been very busy with HipHop, in fact they created a whole new implementation of it (HH itself being an alternative implementation of PHP that compiles to machine-code-compilable C++) that works using Just In Time compilation. Not only is now as fast as it's C++-compiling cousin, but it's steadily getting faster. This reminds me of the Facebook backed experiment to get an implementation of PHP running on the JIT-toting PyPy (Python on Python) from earlier in the year.

Why some people hate PHP
Phil Sturgeon gives a nice roundup of answers to his Quora question - why is it (some) people hate PHP? Most of the reasons there are clear answers to, some may surprise you, and some I still feel there's more we as a community can do to answer/"fix".

First impressions of the Laravel framework
Write of using the Laravel framework for the first time by the University of Kent's Matthew Bull. Laravel is been on my to-try list for a while so it's good to get such a detailed first look.

Micro-optimizing in PHP
We've all done, put a hard reference in that big data loop, switched from a print to echo because ZOMG print is returning something, and the usual hard lesson to learn is to just don't do it because PHP is actually pretty good at runtime optimisation and doing the right thing. The folks from Developer Knowhow give a short roundup of places where micro-optimisations can make a difference, and the intersect with good coding practices.

5 Things Codeignitor Cannot Do (without a rewrite)
Phil Sturgeon again with a list of shortcomings of the Codeignitor framework, most of which already provided by other popular frameworks, and how they could be accomplished..but only with major rewrites in the framework itself.

The Lesser-Known Contributors Who Are Trying To Make PHP Good Again
A slightly older post by Daniel Nill on packages and PHP features making the PHP development ecosystem more rich and pleasant to work in.

PHP Objects Under The Hood
Sherif Ramadan goes deeper into PHPs object and class system than you're likely to have gone before, from how PHP managers symbols in global and local symbol tables to what actually happens when you instance that class into a local variable, or how calls bubble in that stack when accessing this property.

Mongo is dead, long live MongoClient
If you're working with MongoDB in PHP then heads up, the Mongo class is being deprecated and replaced by the nifty new MongoClient class, Dereck Rethans gives us the skinny on why and what you should do to move to the new API. His equally handy follow up post details connection handling with the new class.

The state of meta-programming in PHP
Good write-up by Lars Strojny on meta-programming APIs and toolkits in PHP and third party packages, from the Reflection API to token parsing, AST, runtime symbol adjustments, opcode parsing and meta-data handling. Short story: there's lots you can do with regards reflection and introspection but actual runtime meta-programming is still in the realm of possibly dangerous extensions or memory/CPU heavy parsing, but there are interesting advancements coming up, and for most people it doesn't matter with proper packaging from Composer and meta-models as part of most frameworks, like Zend.

Probing PHP with systemtap on Linux
PHP has had support for DTrace probing points since 5.3, but systemtap is a similar solution for Linux. David Soria Parra recently added support to PHP 5.5 to enable tracing on Linux and details in his blog post how to use systemtap with 5.5.

24 Pull Requests
Not PHP specific but fun nonetheless. This is a project to encourage people to contribute to the world of open source during the festive season by submitting a pull request (you know on GitHub, where everyone seems to be these days) every day up to Christmas. We may be 6 days into that schedule already but there's nothing stopping you catching up, not only is it fun, but it'll help you improve your skills, give you more things to add to your CV, and give something back to projects you probably use every day.

Projects

SimplePHPEasyPlus
A tongue in cheek Mathematical addition library billed as "A simple, pragmatic numeric operation api written in PHP. It does addition." Yes you head right, it does addition, in the most contrived but entirely object-orientated approach possible. This is a nice shot over the barrel at all the OO APIs that we see every day making the simplest of tasks an exercise in Java/C#-like pain. Let's do less of this hey and just make stuff happen? APIs and patterns are important, but not the answer to all things.

FuelPHP Event Package
Framework independent event library, much in the vein of Node.js's EventEmitter.

tagger
A simple and elegant markup generation library that makes great use of fluent interfaces.

nagdash
Nice looking Nagios dashboard billed as modern replacement for Naglite2 (doesn't rely on parsing the much maligned status.dat file that Nagios pushes metrics into) by the same author.

MockServer
Symfony2 mock HTTP server, useful for unit tests that rely on HTTP requests where you can't mock out the client itself.

 

RFCorner

A quick look at what's happenin' in PHP RFCs including implemented changes coming in 5.5.

Generators
Coming in 5.5, generators are a concept that will be familiar if you've done any Python work (or even C#). These are effectively iterable objects that act like arrays but can yield values dynamically on each iteration. Yes you could do this before with the Iterable interface and ArrayAccess, but this removes much of the boilerplate and makes it more intuitive. This API also brings the possibilities of coroutines, but that could be an entire email in itself.

Simplified password hashing
Coming in 5.5, we're finally getting a simple inbuilt framework for generating and verifying secure passwords hashes, using either Bcrypt or PBKDF2. If you want to use this in earlier versions of PHP Anthony Ferrara created this API compatible shim.

try, catch, finally!
Coming in 5.5, the finally keyword has been added to ye olde try-catch blocks to allow you to execute a block of code along with a try block even if an unhandled exceptions occurs. Good examples of this are cleaning up resources regardless of exceptions being thrown inside the catch blog.

list() in foreach()
Coming in 5.5, allow you to expands sub-array values, for example:
foreach ($users as list($firstName, $lastName)) { echo $firstName; }

Enhanced Error Handling
Under discussion, an ongoing discussion about providing a single API for defining how PHP should generate errors and then handle them, including the concept of allowing a single container for all errors to be created, and even how errors are made (e.g. getting real exceptions for inbuilt errors rather than the inbuilt types etc.). I'm all for this and hope an accepted solution is worked out. Also related: Errors as Exceptions.

Function call chaining
and
Object instantiation and property/method call chaining
Under discussion, these similar RFCs would allow us to do things like foo()(); and new foo()->bar();

C# style property accessor/mutator syntax
Under dicussion, if accepted we would be able to define dynamic accessors and mutators for properties (like we do with __get/set*) using a simplified syntax. ECMAScript 6 (next version of JavaScript, effectively) is also getting this.

Upcoming events

SunshinePHP Conference
February 8th-9th 2013
A hot looking conference put on by the Miami PHP community. They had a massive response to their CFP, and holding an extra Symfony track, so looks very promising.

PHP UK
February 22nd-23rd 2013
PHP London user group are putting on the 8th iteration of their annual conference. Looks like some great speakers and talks just announced today, so check it out if you can get to London next year.
